{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising10.txt", "text": "Part 3. ORGANIZATION AND LEADERSHIP  \n   \nTo achieve program and student learning and development outcomes, Academic Advising Programs \n(AAP) must be purposefully structured for effectiveness . AAP must have clearly stated and current  \n\u2022 goals and outcomes  \n\u2022 policies and procedures  \n\u2022 responsibilities and  performance expectations for personnel  \n\u2022 organizational charts demonstrating clear channels of authority  \n \nLeaders must model ethical behavior and institutional citizenship.  \n Leaders with organizational authority for AAP  must provide strategic planning, manag ement and \nsupervision,  and program advancement.  \n Strategic Planning  \n\u2022 articulate a vision and mission that drive short-  and long -term planning  \n\u2022 set goals and objectives based on the needs of the populations served, intended student learning and development outcomes, and program outcomes  \n\u2022 facilitate continuous development, implementation, and assessment of program effectiveness and goal attainment congruent with institutional mission and strategic plans  \n\u2022 promote environments that provide opportunities for stude nt learning, development, and \nengagement  \n\u2022 develop, adapt, and improve programs and services in response to the changing needs of \npopulations served and evolving institutional priorities  \n\u2022 include diverse perspectives to inform decision making  \n \nManagement and Supervision  \n\u2022 plan, allocate, and monitor the use of fiscal, physical, human, intellectual, and technological resources  \n\u2022 manage human resource processes including recruitment, selection, professional development, supervision, performance planning, succession planning, evaluation, recognition, and reward  \n\u2022 influence others to contribute to the effectiveness and success of the unit  \n\u2022 empower professional, support, and student personnel to become effective leaders  \n\u2022 encourage and support collaboration with colleagues and departments across the institution  \n\u2022 encourage and support scholarly contributions to the profession\n", "lemma": "Part ORGANIZATION AND LEADERSHIP achieve program student learning development outcomes, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be purposefully structure effectiveness AAP have clearly state current \u2022 goal outcome \u2022 policy procedure \u2022 responsibility performance expectation personnel \u2022 organizational chart demonstrate clear channel authority Leaders model ethical behavior institutional citizenship. Leaders organizational authority AAP provide strategic planning, manag ement supervision, program advancement. Strategic Planning \u2022 articulate vision mission drive short- long -term planning \u2022 set goal objective base need population served, intend student learning development outcomes, program outcome \u2022 facilitate continuous development, implementation, assessment program effectiveness goal attainment congruent institutional mission strategic plan \u2022 promote environment provide opportunity stude nt learning, development, engagement \u2022 develop, adapt, improve program service response change need population serve evolve institutional priority \u2022 include diverse perspective inform decision make Management Supervision \u2022 plan, allocate, monitor use fiscal, physical, human, intellectual, technological resource \u2022 manage human resource process include recruitment, selection, professional development, supervision, performance planning, succession planning, evaluation, recognition, reward \u2022 influence others contribute effectiveness success unit \u2022 empower professional, support, student personnel become effective leader \u2022 encourage support collaboration colleague department institution \u2022 encourage support scholarly contribution profession"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising11.txt", "text": "\u2022 identify and address individual, organizational, and environmental conditions that foster or \ninhibit mission achievement  \n\u2022 use current and valid evidence to inform decisions  \n\u2022 incorporate sustainability practices in the management and design of programs, services, and \nfacilities  \n\u2022 understand appropriate technologies and integrate them into programs and services  \n\u2022 be knowledgeable about codes and laws relevant to p rograms and services and ensure that \nprograms and services meet those requirements  \n\u2022 assess and take action to mitigate potential risks  \n \nProgram Advancement  \n\u2022 advocate for and actively promote the mission and goals of the programs and services  \n\u2022 inform stakehol ders about issues affecting practice  \n\u2022 facilitate processes to reach consensus where wide support is needed  \n\u2022 advocate for representation in strategic planning initiatives at  divisional and institutional levels  \n \nThe campus community must be able to identify the individual or group coordinating academic advising.   \n \nAAP may be a centralized or decentralized function with a variety of employees throughout the institution assuming responsibilities.  \n Specific advisor responsibilities must be clearly delineated, p ublished, and disseminated to the campus \ncommunity.  \n Advisors must  determine and  articulate the need for administrative, technological, and executive support \nof advising.  \n \n", "lemma": "\u2022 identify address individual, organizational, environmental condition foster inhibit mission achievement \u2022 use current valid evidence inform decision \u2022 incorporate sustainability practice management {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising11.txt", "text": "Part 4. HUMAN RESOURCES  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must be staffed adequately  by individuals qualified to accomplish \nmission and goals.  \n AAP must have access to technical and support personnel adequate to accomplish their mission.  \n \nSupport personnel and technical staff may maintain student records, organize resource materials, rece ive \nstudents, make appointments, handle correspondence, and meet other operational needs, as well as assist with research, data collection, systems development, and special projects.  \n \nWithin institutional guidelines, AAP must  \n\u2022 establish procedures for  perso nnel  recruitment and selection, training, performance planning, and \nevaluation  \n\u2022 set expectations for supervision and performance\n", "lemma": "Part HUMAN RESOURCES Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be staff adequately individual qualify accomplish mission goals. Within institutional guidelines, AAP \u2022 establish procedure perso nnel recruitment selection, training, performance planning, evaluation \u2022 set expectation supervision performance"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising12.txt", "text": "\u2022 provide personnel access to continuing and advanced education and appropriate professional \ndevelopment opportunities to improve their competence, skills,  and leadership capacity  \n\u2022 consider work/life  options available to personnel (e.g., compressed work schedules, flextime, job \nsharing, remote work, or telework) to promote recruitment and retention of personnel  \n \nAdministrators of AAP must  \n\u2022 ensure that all personnel have updated position descriptions  \n\u2022 implement recruitment and selection/hiring strategies that produce a workforce inclusive of under -represented  populations  \n\u2022 develop promotion practices that are fair, in clusive, proactive, and non -discriminatory  \n \nPersonnel responsible for delivery of AAP must have written performance goals, objectives, and outcomes \nfor each year\u2019s performance cycle to be used to plan, review, and evaluate work and performance. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising12.txt", "text": "Results of individual personnel evaluations must be used to recognize personnel performance, address performance issues, implement individual and/or collective personnel development and training programs, and inform the assessment of programs and services. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising14.txt", "text": "Part 5. ETHICS  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must  \n\u2022 review applicable professional ethical standards and must adopt or develop and implement \nappropriate statements of ethical practice  \n\u2022 publish and adhere to statements of ethical practice and ensure their periodic review  \n\u2022 orient new personnel to relevant ethical standards and statements of ethical practice and related \ninstitutional policies  \n \nAdvisors must uphold policies,  procedures, and priorities of their departments and institutions.  \n Statements of ethical standards must  \n\u2022 specify that programs and services personnel respect privacy and maintain confidentiality in \ncommunications and records as delineated by privacy laws  \n\u2022 specify limits on disclosure of information contained in students' records as well as requirements \nto disclose to appropriate authorities  \n\u2022 address conflicts of interest, or appearance thereof, by personnel in the performance of their work  \n\u2022 reflect the respo nsibility of personnel to be fair, objective, and impartial in their interactions with \nothers  \n\u2022 reference management of institutional funds  \n\u2022 reference appropriate behavior regarding research and assessment with human participants, confidentiality of research and assessment data, and students\u2019 rights and responsibilities   \n\u2022 include the expectation that personnel confront and hold accountable other personnel  who exhibit \nunethical behavior  \n\u2022 address issues surrounding scholarly integrity  \n  \nAAP personnel must  \n\u2022 employ e thical decision making in the performance of their duties  \n\u2022 inform users of programs and services of ethical obligations and limitations emanating from codes and laws or from licensure requirements  \n\u2022 recognize and avoid conflicts of interest that could adverse ly influence their judgment or \nobjectivity and, when unavoidable, recuse themselves from the situation\n", "lemma": "Part ETHICS Academic Advising Programs (AAP) \u2022 review applicable professional ethical standard adopt develop implement appropriate statement ethical practice \u2022 procedures, priority department institutions. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising15.txt", "text": "\u2022 perform their duties within the  scope of their position, training, expertise, and competence \n\u2022 make referrals when issues presented exceed the scope of the position  \n \nAAP personnel must recognize their responsibility to ensure the privileged, private, or confidential nature \nof advisors' interactions with students is not sacrificed.    \n \nPart 6. LAW, POLICY, AND GOVERNANCE  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP)  must be in compliance with laws, regulations, and policies that relate \nto their respective responsibilities and that pose legal obligations, limitations, risks, and liabilities for the institution as a whole. Examples include constitutional, statutory, regulato ry, and case law; relevant law \nand orders emanating from codes and laws; and the institution's policies.   \n Advisors  must be  knowledgeable about and sensitive to laws, regulations, policies, and procedures, \nparticularly those governing harassment, use of te chnology, personal relationships with students, privacy \nof student information,  non -discrimination, and equal opportunity policies.  \n AAP must have access to legal advice needed for personnel to carry out their assigned responsibilities.   AAP must inform p ersonnel , appropriate officials, and users of programs and services about existing and \nchanging legal obligations, risks and liabilities, and limitations.  \n AAP must inform personnel about professional liability insurance options and refer them to external  \nsources if the institution does not provide coverage.   \n AAP must have written policies and procedures on operations, transactions, or tasks that have legal \nimplications.  \n \nAAP must regularly review policies. The revision and creation of policies must be in formed by best \npractices, available evidence, and policy issues in higher education.  \n \nAAP must have procedures and guidelines consistent with institutional policy for responding to threats, emergencies, and crisis situations. Systems and procedures must be  in place to disseminate timely and \naccurate information to students, other members of the institutional community, and appropriate external \norganizations during emergency situations.  \n \nPersonnel must neither participate in nor condone any form of harassme nt or activity that demeans \npersons or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive environment.  \n AAP must purchase or obtain  permission to use copyrighted materials and instruments.  ", "lemma": "\u2022 perform duty scope position, training, expertise, competence \u2022 make referral issue present exceed scope position AAP personnel recognize responsibility ensure privileged, private, confidential nature advisors' interaction student be not sacrificed. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising16.txt", "text": "Part 7. DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND ACCESS   \n \nWithin the context of each institution's mission and in accordance with institutional policies and \napplicable codes and laws, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must create and maintain educational and \nwork environments that are welcoming, accessible, inclusive, equitable, and free from harassment .  \n AAP must not discriminate on the basis of disability; age; race; cultural identity; ethnicity; nationality; family educational history (e.g., first generation to attend college); political affiliation; religious affiliation; sex; sexual orientation; gender  identity and expression; marital, social, economic, or veteran status; or any \nother basis included in institutional policies and codes and laws.  \n AAP must  \n\u2022 advocate for  sensitivity to multicultural and social justice concerns by the institution and its \npersonnel  \n\u2022 ensure physical, program, and resource access for all constituents  \n\u2022 modify or remove policies, practices, systems,  technologies, facilities, and structures that create \nbarriers or produce inequities  \n\u2022 ensure that when facilities and structures cannot be modified, they do not impede access to programs, services and resources  \n\u2022 establish goals for diversity, equity, and access  \n\u2022 foster communication and practices that  enhance understanding of identity, culture, self -\nexpression, and heritage  \n\u2022 promote respect for commonalities and differences among people within their historical and \ncultural contexts  \n\u2022 address the characteristics and needs of  diverse  constituents when establishing and implementing \nculturally relevant and inclusive programs, services, policies, pr ocedures, and practices  \n\u2022 provide  personnel  with diversity, equity, and access training and hold personnel accountable for \napplying the training to their work  \n\u2022 respond to the needs of all constituents served when establishing hours of operation and developing  methods of delivering programs, services, and resources  \n\u2022 recognize the needs of distance and online learning students by directly providing or assisting them to gain access to comparable services and resources   \n \nPart 8. INTERNAL  AND EXTERNAL RELATIONS  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must reach out to  individuals, groups, communities, and \norganizations internal and external to the institution to  \n\u2022 establish, maintain, and promote understanding and effective relations with those that have a significant interest in or potential effect on the students or other constituents served by the \nprograms and services\n", "lemma": "Part DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND ACCESS context institution's mission accordance institutional policy applicable code laws, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) create maintain educational work environment be welcoming, accessible, inclusive, equitable, free harassment AAP not discriminate basis disability; age; race; cultural identity; ethnicity; family educational history (e.g., first generation attend college); political affiliation; religious affiliation; sex; sexual orientation; gender identity expression; marital, social, economic, veteran status; other basis include institutional policy code laws. AAP \u2022 advocate sensitivity multicultural social justice concern institution personnel \u2022 ensure physical, program, resource access constituent \u2022 modify remove policies, practices, systems, technologies, facilities, structure create barrier produce inequity \u2022 ensure facility structure cannot be modified, do not impede access programs, service resource \u2022 establish goal diversity, equity, access \u2022 foster communication practice enhance understanding identity, culture, expression, heritage \u2022 promote respect commonality difference people historical cultural context \u2022 characteristic need diverse constituent establish implement culturally relevant inclusive programs, services, policies, pr ocedures, practice \u2022 provide personnel diversity, equity, access training hold personnel accountable apply training work \u2022 respond need constituent serve establish hour operation develop method deliver programs, services, resource \u2022 recognize need distance online learning student directly provide assist gain access comparable service resource Part INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL RELATIONS Academic Advising Programs (AAP) reach out individuals, groups, communities, organization internal external institution \u2022 establish, maintain, promote understanding effective relation have significant interest potential effect student other constituent serve program service"}

{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising17.txt", "text": "Part 9. FINANCIAL RESOURCES  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP) must have  funding to accomplish the mission and goals.   \n In establishing and prioritizing funding resources, AAP must conduct comprehensive analyses  to \ndetermine  \n\u2022 unmet needs of the unit  \n\u2022 relevant expenditures  \n\u2022 external and internal resources  \n\u2022 impact on students and the institution  \n \nAAP must use the budget as a planning tool to reflect commitment to the mission and goals of the \nprograms and services and of the institution.  \n \nAAP must administer funds in accordance with established institutional accounting procedures.  \n \nAAP must demonstrate efficient and effective use and responsible stewardship of fiscal resources \nconsistent with institutional protocols.  \n \nFinancial resources should be used to  raise awareness  of the academic advising program and its value to a \nrange of st akeholders.  \n \nSufficient institutional and financial resources must be provided to assist professional development of \nacademic advisors.\n", "lemma": "Part FINANCIAL RESOURCES Academic Advising Programs (AAP) have funding accomplish mission goals. establish prioritize funding resources, AAP conduct comprehensive analysis determine \u2022 unmet need unit \u2022 relevant expenditures \u2022 external internal resource \u2022 impact student institution AAP use budget planning tool reflect commitment mission goal program service institution. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising18.txt", "text": "The technology and its use must comply with institutional policies and procedures and with relevant codes and laws.  \n AAP must use technologies to  \n\u2022 provide updated information regarding mission, location, staffing, programs, services, and official contacts to students and other constituents in accessible formats  \n\u2022 provide an avenue for students and other constituents to communicate sensitive information in a secure format  \n\u2022 enhance the delivery of programs and services for all students  \n \nAAP must  employ technologies that facilitate interaction with students in the advising process.   \n \nAAP must ensure that online and technology -assisted advising includes appropriate processes for \nobtaining approvals, consultations, and referrals.  \n AAP must  \n\u2022 back up data on a regular basis  \n\u2022 adhere to institutional policies regarding ethical and legal use of technology  \n\u2022 articulate policies and procedures for protecting the confidentiality and security of information  \n\u2022 implement a replacement plan and cycle for all techn ology with attention to sustainability  \n\u2022 incorporate accessibility features into technology -based programs and services  \n When providing student access to technology, AAP must  \n\u2022 have policies on the use of technology that are clear, easy to understand, and ava ilable to all \nstudents  \n\u2022 provide  information or referral to support services for those needing assistance in  accessing or \nusing technology  \n\u2022 provide instruction or training on how to use the technology  \n\u2022 inform students of implications of misuse of technologies\n", "lemma": "technology use comply institutional policy procedure relevant code laws. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising19.txt", "text": "Part 11. FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT  \n \nAcademic Advising  Programs\u2019 (AAP) facilities must be intentionally designed and located in suitable, \naccessible, and safe spaces that demonstrate universal design and support the program\u2019s mission and goals.  \n \nFacilities must be designed to engage various constituents and promote learning.  \n Personnel must have workspaces that are suitably located and accessible, well equipped, adequate in size, \nand designed to support their work and responsibilities.   \n AAP must provide  work space that is private and free from visual and auditory distractions.  \n The design of the facilities must guarantee the security and privacy of records and ensure the \nconfidentiality of sensitive information and conversations. Personnel must b e able to secure their work.  \n \nAAP must incorporate sustainable practices in use of facilities and purchase of equipment. Facilities and equipment must be evaluated on an established cycle and be in compliance with codes, laws, and accepted practices for a ccess, health, safety and security.  \n When acquiring capital equipment, AAP must take into account expenses related to regular maintenance and life cycle costs .  \n \n", "lemma": "Part FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT Academic Advising Programs\u2019 (AAP) facility be intentionally design locate suitable, accessible, safe space demonstrate universal design support program\u2019s mission goals. Facilities be design engage various constituent promote learning. Personnel have workspace be suitably locate accessible, well equipped, adequate size, design support work responsibilities. AAP provide work space be private free visual auditory distractions. design facility guarantee security privacy record ensure confidentiality sensitive information conversations. Personnel b e able secure work. AAP incorporate sustainable practice use facility purchase equipment. Facilities equipment be evaluate establish cycle be compliance codes, laws, accept practice ccess, health, safety security. acquire capital equipment, AAP take account expense relate regular maintenance life cycle cost"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising19.txt", "text": "Part 12. ASSESSMENT  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP) must develop assessment plans and proces ses. \n \nAssessment plans must articulate an ongoing cycle of assessment activities.  \n AAP must  \n\u2022 specify programmatic goals and intended outcomes  \n\u2022 identify student learning and development outcomes  \n\u2022 employ multiple measures and methods  \n\u2022 develop manageable processes for gathering, interpreting, and evaluating data  \n\u2022 document progress toward achievement of goals and outcomes   \n\u2022 interpret and use assessment results to demonstrate accountability  \n\u2022 report aggregated results to respondent groups and stakeholders  \n\u2022 use assessment results to inform planning and decision -making  \n\u2022 assess effectiveness of implemented changes  \n\u2022 provide evidence of improvement  of programs and services  \n AAP must employ ethical practices in the assessment process.\n", "lemma": "Part ASSESSMENT Academic Advising Programs (AAP) develop assessment plan proces ses. Assessment plan articulate ongoing cycle assessment activities. AAP \u2022 specify programmatic goal intend outcome \u2022 identify student learn development outcome \u2022 employ multiple measure method \u2022 develop manageable process gathering, interpreting, evaluate data \u2022 document progress achievement goal outcome \u2022 interpret use assessment result demonstrate accountability \u2022 report aggregate result respondent group stakeholder \u2022 use assessment result inform planning decision -making \u2022 ass effectiveness implemented change \u2022 provide evidence improvement program service AAP employ ethical practice assessment process."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising2.txt", "text": "ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS  \nCAS  Contextual Statement  \n \nAcademic advising is an essential element in the success and persistence of postsecondary students (Klepfer &  Hull, \n2012). Although an institution\u2019s culture, values, and practices affect the organization and delivery of advising \n(Habley, 1997), practitioners directly influence personal, institutional, and societal success. Specifically, they help \nstudents \u2018\u2018become members of their higher education community, think critically about their roles and \nresponsibilities as students, and prepare to be educated citizens of a democratic society and a global community \u2019\u2019 \n(National Academic Advising Association [NACADA], 2006, p ara. 7); that is, regardless of the delivery mechanism, \nthrough academic advising, students learn to make the most of their college experience (Miller, 2012, para. 1). As \nhigher education curricula grow increasingly complex and constituents demand accounta bility, stakeholders feel the \npressure to make students\u2019 academic experience as meaningful as possible. Academic advising professionals must be \nready to meet these challenges.  \n The growth of academic advising mirrors the growth and changes in higher education (Cook, 2009; Thelin & \nHirschy, 2009). In the 1870s, electives introduced in the academic curriculum meant advisors needed \u2018\u2018 to guide \nstudents in the successful pursuit of their chosen paths \u2019\u2019 (Kuhn, 2008, p. 5). The 1970s ushered in a new era for \nacademi c advising with O\u2019Banion\u2019s (1972/1994/2009) and Crookston\u2019s (1972/1994/2009) articles advocating a \ndevelopmental academic -advising approach. Today, the advising community recognizes more than a dozen \nrelational styles of academic advising (Drake, Jordan, &  Miller, 2013). Each approach encourages professional, \nfaculty, and peer advisors to help students delineate their academic, career, and life goals as they help students craft \nthe educational plans necessary to complete their postsecondary objectives. ", "lemma": "ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS CAS Contextual Statement Academic advising be essential element success persistence postsecondary student (Klepfer Hull, institution\u2019s culture, values, practice affect organization delivery advise (Habley, practitioner directly influence personal, institutional, societal success. Specifically, help student \u2018\u2018become member high education community, think critically role responsibility students, prepare be educate citizen democratic society global community \u2019\u2019 (National Academic Advising Association [NACADA], p ara. is, regardless delivery mechanism, academic advising, student learn make most college experience (Miller, para. high education curriculum grow increasingly complex constituent demand accounta bility, stakeholder feel pressure make students\u2019 academic experience as meaningful possible. Academic advising professional be ready meet challenges. growth academic advise mirror growth change high education Thelin Hirschy, elective introduce academic curriculum mean advisor need \u2018\u2018 guide student successful pursuit chosen path \u2019\u2019 (Kuhn, p. ushered new era academi c advise O\u2019Banion\u2019s (1972/1994/2009) Crookston\u2019s (1972/1994/2009) article advocate developmental academic -advising approach. Today, advise community recognize more dozen relational style academic advise (Drake, Jordan, Miller, approach encourage professional, faculty, peer advisor help student delineate academic, career, life goal help student craft educational plan necessary complete postsecondary objectives."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising2.txt", "text": "Thes e approaches are often customized \nto meet the diverse needs of today\u2019s college student (Drake, Jordan, & Miller, 2013).  \n In 1977, the National Academic Advising Association (NACADA) was formed to provide direction and purpose for \npracticing academic adviso rs (Grites & Gordon, 2009). Today, NACADA flourishes with more than 12,000 members \nin over 30 countries. The NACADA Statement of Core Values (NACADA, 2005) offers the ethical principles that guide advising practice. Along with the NACADA Concept of Academi c Advising (NACADA, 2006) and the CAS \nStandards, the Core Values serve as a framework all academic advisors can use to examine their professional practice. Information on the NACADA resources, programs, and services can be found at www.nacada.ksu.edu.  \n \nAs those in higher education, including academic advisors, respond to a changing postsecondary environment, they \nmust structure exemplary practices, pay particular attention to key institutional learning outcomes, serve the distinctive needs of a range of stu dent populations, and promote national agendas on degree completion (Drake, \nJordan, & Miller, 2013). The strong emphasis on research in academic advising reflects today\u2019s focus on student \nretention and graduation. Klepfer and Hull (2012) noted \u2018\u2018 the strengt h of academic advising as a factor in \npersistence. College students who reported visiting with advisors frequently had a much greater likelihood of persisting than their peers who never did \u2019\u2019 (para. 17). NACADA Concept Academi c Advising CAS Standards, Core Values serve framework academic advisor use examine professional practice. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising4.txt", "text": "order the pieces, put them toge ther to make a coherent whole, so that the student experiences the curriculum not as \na checklist of discrete, isolated pieces but instead as a unity, a composition of interrelated parts with multiple \nconnections and relationships \u2019\u2019 (para. 5). Academic advis ors meet these obligations through applying frameworks for \ngood practice, including building partnerships with pivotal campus offices such as orientation, first -year student \nprograms, and career services.  \n \nAs the NACADA Concept of Academic Advising (NACADA, 2006)  delineates, academic advising objectives differ \namong institutions based upon the particular mission, goals, curriculum, co -curriculum, and assessment methods \nestablished for the respective campus (White, 2000). However, a representative sample of learning outcomes for \nadvising indicates that students will  \n\u2022 craft a coherent educational plan based on assessment of abilities, aspirations, interests, and values;  \n\u2022 use complex information from various sources to set goals, reach decisions, and achieve those goals;  \n\u2022 assume responsibility for meeting academic program requirements;  \n\u2022 articulate the meaning of higher education and the intent of the institution\u2019s curriculum;  \n\u2022 cultivate the intellectual habits that lead to a lifetime of learning; and  \n\u2022 behave as ci tizens who engage in the wider world around them (NACADA, 2006, para. 10).  \n \nThe increasing public attention placed on college completion means increased visibility for academic advising. \nReports such as Guided Pathways to Success  (Complete College America, 2013) point to academic advising as vital to \ndegree completion.  As institutions seek to increase and diversify enrollments, academic advisors are vital to ensuring \nappropriate matriculation and transfer leading to degree complet ion for all students. The evolving manner by which \nstudents complete college degrees, including the blending of courses offered on a variety of campuses and online, \nplaces new challenges on academic advisors, who must possess the tools needed to meet the d emands of students in \nvirtual space and across multiple institutions (Compete College America, 2013).  \n \nA crucial component of the college experience, academic advising encourages students to cultivate meaning in their \nlives, make significant decisions abou t their futures, and access institutional resources. When practiced with \ncompetence and dedication, academic advising is integral to student success, persistence, retention, and completion. Therefore, academic advisors must develop the tools and skills nec essary to address the many issues that influence \nstudent success and do so with respect to the increasing diversity on college and university campuses. The standards and guidelines in the Academic Advising Program Standards provide a framework for developi ng strong academic \nadvising programs.  \n \nReferences, Readings, and Resources  \n \nComplete College America. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising7.txt", "text": "ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS  \nCAS  Standards and Guidelines  \n \nPart 1. MISSION  \n \nThe mission of Academic Advising Programs (AAP) is to assist students as they define, plan, and achieve their educational goals. The AAP must advocate for student success and persistence.   AAP must develop, disseminate, implement, and regularly review their missions, which must be consistent with the mission of the institution and with applicable professional standards.  The mission must be \nappropriate for the institution's students  and other constituents. Mission statements must reference \nstudent learni ng and development.  \n \nThe specific model used for AAP should be consistent with the mission, structure, and resources of the \ninstitution.  \n \n", "lemma": "ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS CAS Standards Guidelines Part MISSION mission Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be assist student define, plan, achieve educational goals. AAP advocate student success persistence. AAP develop, disseminate, implement, regularly review missions, be consistent mission institution applicable professional standards. mission be appropriate institution's student other constituents. Mission statement reference student learni ng development. specific model use AAP be consistent mission, structure, resource institution."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising7.txt", "text": "Part 2. PROGRAM   \n \nTo achieve their mission, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must contribute to  \n\u2022 students' formal educa tion, which includes both the curriculum and the co -curriculum  \n\u2022 student progression and timely completion of educational goals  \n\u2022 preparation of students for their careers, citizenship, and lives  \n\u2022 student learning  and development  \n \nTo contribute to student learning and development, AAP must  \n\u2022 identify relevant and desirable student learning and development  outcomes  \n\u2022 articulate how the student learning and development outcomes align with the six CAS student learning and development domains and related dimensions  \n\u2022 asse ss relevant and desirable student learning and development  \n\u2022 provide evidence of impact on outcomes  \n\u2022 articulate contributions to or support of student learning and development in the domains not specifically assessed  \n\u2022 use evidence gathered to create strategies for improvement of programs and services  \n \nSTUDENT LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT DOMAINS AND DIMENSIONS  \n \nDomain: knowledge acquisition, integration, construction, and application  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: understanding knowledge from a range of disciplines; connecting knowledge to other knowledge, ideas, and experiences; constructing knowledge; and relating knowledge to daily life \n \nDomain: cognitive complexity\n", "lemma": "Part PROGRAM achieve mission, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) contribute \u2022 students' formal educa tion, include curriculum co -curriculum \u2022 student progression timely completion educational goal \u2022 preparation student careers, citizenship, live \u2022 student learning development contribute student learning development, AAP \u2022 identify relevant desirable student learning development outcome \u2022 articulate student learning development outcome align CAS student learn development domain related dimension \u2022 asse s relevant desirable student learning development \u2022 provide evidence impact outcome \u2022 articulate contribution support student learning development domain not specifically assessed \u2022 use evidence gather create strategy improvement program service STUDENT LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT DOMAINS AND DIMENSIONS Domain: knowledge acquisition, integration, construction, application \u2022 Dimensions: understand knowledge range disciplines; connect knowledge other knowledge, ideas, experiences; constructing knowledge; relate knowledge daily life Domain: cognitive complexity"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising8.txt", "text": "\u2022 Dimensions: critical thinking, reflective thinking, effective reasonin g, and creativity  \n \nDomain: intrapersonal development  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: realistic self -appraisal, self -understanding, and self -respect; identity development; \ncommitment to ethics and integrity; and spiritual awareness  \n \nDomain: interpersonal competence  \n \n\u2022 Dimension s: meaningful relationships, interdependence, collaboration, and effective leadership  \n \nDomain: humanitarianism and civic engagement  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: understanding and appreciation of cultural and human differences, social \nresponsibility, global perspective, and sense of civic responsibility  \n \nDomain: practical competence  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: pursuing goals, communicating effectively, technical competence, managing \npersonal affairs, managing career development, demonstrating professionalism, maintaining \nhealth and wellness, and living a purposeful and satisfying life  \n \n[LD Outcomes: See The Council for the Advancement of Standards Learning and Development Outcomes  statement for \nexamples of outcomes related to these domains and dimensions.]  \n \nAAP should determine which of the CAS learning and development domains and dimensions are most relevant to the advising functions on their campus and develop appropriate outcomes.  \n \n", "lemma": "\u2022 Dimensions: critical thinking, reflective thinking, effective reasonin g, creativity Domain: intrapersonal development \u2022 Dimensions: realistic self -appraisal, self -understanding, -respect; {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising8.txt", "text": "AAP must be  \n\u2022 intentionally designed  \n\u2022 guided by theories and knowledge of learning and development  \n\u2022 integrated into the life of the institution  \n\u2022 reflective of developmental and demographic profiles of the student population  \n\u2022 responsive to needs of individuals, populations with distinct needs, and relevant constituencies  \n\u2022 delivered using multiple formats, st rategies, and contexts  \n\u2022 designed to provide universal access  \n \nAAP must collaborate with colleagues and departments across the institution to promote student learning \nand development, persistence, and success.  \n AAP must provide the same quality of academic advising and in the appropriate  accessible forums to \ndistance learners as it does to students on campus.  \n Advisors must engage students in the shared responsibility of academic advising.\n", "lemma": "AAP be \u2022 intentionally design \u2022 guide theory knowledge learn development \u2022 integrate life institution \u2022 reflective developmental demographic profile student population \u2022 responsive need individuals, population distinct needs, relevant constituency \u2022 deliver use multiple formats, st rategies, context \u2022 design provide universal access AAP collaborate colleague department institution promote student learning development, persistence, success. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising9.txt", "text": "Advisors must provide opportunities that help inform student choice s and decisions about academic work \nand about educational, career, and life goals.  \n \nAdvisors should inform students that the ultimate responsibility for making decisions about educational plans \nand life goals rests with the individual student.    \n \nAAP must  be guided by a set of written goals and objectives that are directly related to its stated mission.   \n \nAcademic advisors should offer advising sessions in a format that is private and safe. ", "lemma": "Advisors provide opportunity help inform student choice s decision academic work educational, career, life goals. Advisors inform student ultimate responsibility make decision educational plan life goal rest individual student. AAP be guide set write goal objective be directly relate state mission. Academic advisor offer advise session format be private safe."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising9.txt", "text": "Sessions should be convenient and accessible to the student, emplo ying the use of electronic and multimedia formats and \ntraditional in -person or telephone interactions as appropriate. Advising information sessions may be carried \nout individually or in groups, depending on the needs of the student and always with the stud ent's consent.  \n \nPrograms and  materials  associated with the AAP must   \n\u2022 promote student learning, development, and personal growth to encourage self -sufficiency  \n\u2022 support students, on an ongoing basis, as they establish and evaluate their educational, career, and life goals  \n\u2022 assist students in identifying the realistic timeframe to complete their educational goals and support their efforts  \n\u2022 provide  current and accurate advising information  \n\u2022 raise awareness  of institutional and community resources and services for students  \n\u2022 provide advisors with  training and development for making effective referrals to both on - and off-\ncampus services and agencies  \n\u2022 make advising available to students throughout their time at the institution  \n\u2022 proactively identify academically at -risk students and connect those students  with appropriate \nresources to facilitate student success  \n\u2022 employ appropriate and accessible technology to support the delivery of advising information  \n\u2022 clarify institutional policies and procedures for students  \n\u2022 monitor  academic progress and direct students to appropriate resources and programs  \n\u2022 advocate for appropriate resources to facilitate student success  \n\u2022 support learning and professional development for those involved in delivery of academic advising  \n\u2022 collect and d istribute relevant data regarding student needs, preferences, and performance for use \nin institutional decisions and policy  \n AAP must provide adequate resources to ensure that academic advising caseloads are consistent with the institutional mission and stated goals.    \n \nWhen institutional policy or process interferes with students' learning and development, the AAP must \nadvocate  for change using appropriate institutional means.  \n \nFactors that affect determination of advising caseloads include mode of delivery, advising approach used, \nadditional advisor responsibilities, student needs, and time required for this activity.\n", "lemma": "Sessions be convenient accessible student, emplo ying use electronic multimedia format traditional -person telephone interaction appropriate. Advising information session be carry out individually groups, depend need student always stud ent's consent. Programs material associate AAP \u2022 promote student learning, development, personal growth encourage self -sufficiency \u2022 support students, ongoing basis, establish evaluate educational, career, life goal \u2022 assist student identify realistic timeframe complete educational goal support effort provide current accurate advise information \u2022 raise awareness institutional community resource service student \u2022 provide advisor training development make effective referral off- campus service agency \u2022 make advise available student time institution \u2022 proactively identify academically -risk student connect student appropriate resource facilitate student success \u2022 employ appropriate accessible technology support delivery advise information \u2022 clarify institutional policy procedure student \u2022 monitor academic progress direct student appropriate resource program \u2022 advocate appropriate resource facilitate student success \u2022 support learning professional development involve delivery academic advise \u2022 collect d istribute relevant data regard student needs, preferences, performance use institutional decision policy AAP provide adequate resource ensure academic advise caseloads be consistent institutional mission state goals. institutional policy process interferes students' learning development, AAP advocate change use appropriate institutional means. Factors affect determination advise caseloads include mode delivery, advise approach used, additional advisor responsibilities, student needs, time require activity."}

{"source": "Changes to RH131 and RH3300.txt", "text": "Dear academic advisors,  \n \nI\u2019m writing to alert you to revisions to the HSSA writing curriculum that Curriculum Committee passed \nthis month. These changes will be reflected in next year\u2019s catalog and degree requirements for our \nincoming freshmen \u2014but will also affect registration for  the small number of returning students who \nhave not yet earned credit for RH131 Rhetoric and Composition.  \n \nThe short version:  \nRH131  Rhetoric and Composition is replaced by  HUM H190  First -Year Writing Seminar  \nRH330  Technical and Professional Communication is renumbered as  ENGL H290  Technical and \nProfessional Communication  \n \nThe details:  \nIn addition to updating course numbers to fit the rest of the HSSA courses, this curriculum change \nrevises our approach to first -year writing. First -Year Writing Seminars ado pt a specific thematic focus in \na foundational course for our students\u2019 liberal education experience, including key learning outcomes \nfor critical thinking and communication. The thematic seminar approach is typical not only of liberal arts \ncolleges, but a lso of other elite private polytechnic schools \u2014HUM H190 closely resembles similar \ncourses at Harvey Mudd, Olin, and Rensselaer. ", "lemma": "Dear academic advisors, I\u2019m writing alert revisions HSSA writing curriculum Curriculum Committee pass month. change be reflect next year\u2019s catalog degree requirement incoming freshman \u2014but also affect registration small number return student have not yet earn credit RH131 Rhetoric Composition. short version: RH131 Rhetoric Composition be replace HUM H190 First -Year Writing Seminar RH330 Technical Professional Communication be renumbered ENGL H290 Technical Professional Communication details: addition update course number fit rest HSSA courses, curriculum change revise approach first -year writing. {"source": "Chronic%20Health%20and%20Medical%20Conditions%20Guidance%20a0.txt", "text": "When a chronic health or medical condition substantially limits one or more \nmajor life activity, it is considered a disability.  Cancer, narcolepsy, migraine disorder, \ntraumatic brain injury, diabetes, insomnia, allergies, fibromyalgia , spinal ankylosis are \nconditions that have impacted our Rose -Hulman students.  \nhttps://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/42/12102  \n \n\u2022 Speech may or may not be impacted due to condition   \n\u2022 Verbal r esponse may or may not be delayed   \n\u2022 Audio processing may or may not be impacted due to \ncondition  \n\u2022 Student may appear lethargic/uninterested  \n \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty with handwriting and note taking  \n\u2022 Movement may be slow  \n\u2022 May have sensory defensiveness to light o r noise  \n\u2022 May have difficulty remaining seated  \n \n \n \n\u2022 Ability to concentrate may be impacted  \n\u2022 May miss verbal directions  \n\u2022 May appear to be uninterested or lacking in enthusiasm for \nprojects or collaborative work  \n\u2022 May need to have medical absences\n", "lemma": "chronic health medical condition substantially limit more major life be consider disability. {"source": "Concept of Advising0.txt", "text": "Concept of Academic Advising   \nReprinted with permission from NACADA: The Global Community for Academi c \nAdvising  www.nacada.ksu.edu.   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \nPREAMBLE   \nAcademic advising is integral to fulfilling the teaching and learning mission of higher education. \nThrough academic advising, students learn to become members of their higher  education \ncommunity, to think critically about their roles and responsibilities as students, and to prepare \nto be educated citizens of a democratic society and a global community. ", "lemma": "Concept Academic Advising Reprinted permission NACADA: Global Community Academi c Advising www.nacada.ksu.edu. PREAMBLE Academic advising be integral fulfil teaching learn mission high education. academic advising, student learn become member high education community, think critically role responsibility students, prepare be educate citizen democratic society global community."}
{"source": "Concept of Advising0.txt", "text": "Academic advising \nengages students beyond their own world views, while ackn owledging their individual \ncharacteristics, values, and motivations as they enter, move through, and exit the institution. \nRegardless of the diversity of our institutions, our students, our advisors, and our organizational \nstructures, academic advising has  three components: curriculum (what advising deals with), \npedagogy (how advising does what it does), and student learning outcomes (the result of \nacademic advising).  \nTHE CURRICULUM OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nAcademic advising draws primarily from theories in t he social sciences, humanities, and \neducation. The curriculum of academic advising ranges from the ideals of higher education to \nthe pragmatics of enrollment. This curriculum includes, but is not limited to, the institution\u2019s \nmission, culture and expectati ons; the meaning, value, and interrelationship of the institution\u2019s \ncurriculum and co -curriculum; modes of thinking, learning, and decision -making; the selection \nof academic programs and courses; the development of life and career goals; \ncampus/community r esources, policies, and procedures; and the transferability of skills and \nknowledge.\n", "lemma": "Academic advise engages student own world views, ackn owledging individual characteristics, values, motivation enter, move through, exit institution. Regardless diversity institutions, students, advisors, organizational structures, academic advising have components: curriculum advise deal with), pedagogy (how advise do does), student learn outcome (the result academic THE CURRICULUM OF ACADEMIC ADVISING Academic advise draw primarily theory t social sciences, humanities, education. curriculum academic advise range ideal high education pragmatic enrollment. curriculum includes, be not limited institution\u2019s mission, culture expectati ons; meaning, value, interrelationship institution\u2019s curriculum co -curriculum; mode thinking, learning, decision -making; selection academic program courses; development life career goals; campus/community r esources, policies, procedures; transferability skill knowledge."}
{"source": "Concept of Advising1.txt", "text": "THE PEDAGOGY OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nAcademic advising, as a teaching and learning process, requires a pedagogy that incorporates \nthe preparation, facilitation, documentati on, and assessment of advising interactions. Although \nthe specific methods, strategies, and techniques may vary, the relationship between advisors \nand students is fundamental and is characterized by mutual respect, trust, and ethical behavior.  \nSTUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nThe student learning outcomes of academic advising are guided by an institution\u2019s mission, \ngoals, curriculum and co -curriculum. These outcomes, defined in an advising curriculum, \narticulate what students will  demonstrate, know, value, and do as a result of participating in \nacademic advising. Each institution must develop its own set of student learning outcomes and \nthe methods to assess them. ", "lemma": "PEDAGOGY OF ACADEMIC ADVISING Academic advising, teaching learn process, require pedagogy incorporate preparation, facilitation, documentati on, assessment advise interactions. specific methods, strategies, technique vary, relationship advisor student be fundamental be characterize mutual respect, trust, ethical behavior. STUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES OF ACADEMIC ADVISING student learn outcome academic advising be guide institution\u2019s mission, goals, curriculum co -curriculum. outcomes, define advise curriculum, articulate student demonstrate, know, value, do result participate academic advising. institution develop own set student learn outcome method assess them."}
{"source": "Concept of Advising1.txt", "text": "The following is a representative sample. Students will:  \n\uf0a7 craft a co herent educational plan based on assessment of abilities, aspirations, interests, and \nvalues  \n\uf0a7 use complex information from various sources to set goals, reach decisions, and achieve \nthose goals  \n\uf0a7 assume responsibility for meeting academic program requirements  \n\uf0a7 articulate the meaning of higher education and the intent of the institution\u2019s curriculum  \n\uf0a7 cultivate the intellectual habits that lead to a lifetime of learning  \n\uf0a7 behave as citizens who engage in the wider world around them  \n \nSUMMARY   \nAcademic advising, based in the teaching and learning mission of higher education, is a series of \nintentional interactions with a curriculum, a pedagogy, and a set of student learning outcomes. \nAcademic advising synthesizes and contextualizes students\u2019 educational experiences with in the \nframeworks of their aspirations, abilities and lives to extend learning beyond campus \nboundaries and timeframes.\n", "lemma": "following be representative sample. Students will: \uf0a7 craft co herent educational plan base assessment abilities, aspirations, interests, value \uf0a7 use complex information various source set goals, reach decisions, achieve goal \uf0a7 assume responsibility meet academic program requirement \uf0a7 articulate meaning high education intent institution\u2019s curriculum \uf0a7 cultivate intellectual habit lead lifetime learn \uf0a7 behave citizen engage wider world SUMMARY Academic advising, base teaching learn mission high education, be series intentional interaction curriculum, pedagogy, set student learn outcomes. Academic advising synthesizes contextualizes students\u2019 educational experience framework aspirations, ability life extend learn campus boundary timeframes."}
{"source": "Core Competencies0.txt", "text": "At the request of the association\u2019s leadership, the NACADA Academic Advising Core Competencies Model  \n(2017) was developed by the association\u2019s Professional Development Committee.  The purpose of the model is to \nidentify the broad range of understanding, knowledge, and skills that support academic advising, to guide professional development, and to promote the contributions of advising to student development, progress, and success.  It is intended that the model may be used by:\n\u2022 Primary Role Advisors  for self-assessment and evaluation, and to guide learning, career development, and \nadvancement. \n\u2022 Faculty Advisors and Advising Administrators  to clarify academic advising roles and responsibilities, and to \nhighlight the contributions of academic advising to teaching and learning.\n\u2022 Advising Supervisors, Managers, and Mentors  to identify strengths and areas for staff development, and to \nguide hiring, training, and evaluation.\n", "lemma": "request association\u2019s leadership, NACADA Academic Advising Core Competencies Model (2017) be develop association\u2019s Professional Development Committee. purpose model be identify broad range understanding, knowledge, skill support academic advising, guide professional development, promote contribution advise student development, progress, success. be intend model be use by: \u2022 Primary Role Advisors self-assessment evaluation, guide learning, career development, advancement. \u2022 Faculty Advisors Advising Administrators clarify academic advise role responsibilities, highlight contribution academic advise teach learning. \u2022 Advising Supervisors, Managers, Mentors identify strength area staff development, guide hiring, training, evaluation."}
{"source": "Core Competencies0.txt", "text": "\u2022 Learning Professionals, Trainers, and Researchers  to support curriculum development, establish learning \npriorities, and advance scholarship in the field.\nUnderpinning the core competencies for academic advising and serving as the foundational elements for effective advisor training programs and advising practice are three content components \u2013 the conceptual, informational, and relational.  An understanding of these content areas provides advisors the knowledge and skills to be effective guides for their students. \n \n\u2022 The Conceptual component provides the context for \nthe delivery of academic advising.  It covers the ideas and theories that advisors must understand to effectively advise their students.\n\u2022 The Informational component provides the substance \nof academic advising.  It covers the knowledge advisors must gain to be able to guide the students at their institution.\n\u2022 The Relational component provides the skills that \nenable academic advisors to convey the concepts and information from the other two components to their advisees.\nTo achieve excellence in their work, regardless of the specifics of their individual campus\u2019 advising mission, all academic advisors must understand all three components and be able to synthesize and apply them as needed in academic advising interactions.\n", "lemma": "\u2022 Learning Professionals, Trainers, Researchers support curriculum development, establish learning priorities, advance scholarship field. Underpinning core competency academic advising serving foundational element effective advisor training program advise practice be content component \u2013 conceptual, informational, relational. understanding content area provide advisor knowledge skill be effective guide students. Conceptual component provide context delivery academic advising. cover idea theory advisor understand effectively advise students. Informational component provide substance academic advising. cover knowledge advisor gain be able guide student institution. Relational component provide skill enable academic advisor convey concept information other component advisees. achieve excellence work, regardless specific individual campus\u2019 advise academic advisor understand component be able synthesize apply need academic advising interactions."}
{"source": "Core Competencies1.txt", "text": "Core competencies in the Conceptual component (concepts academic advisors must understand) include \nunderstanding of:  \n1. The history and role of academic advising in higher education.  ", "lemma": "Core competency Conceptual component (concepts academic advisor understand) include understanding of: history role academic advising high education."}
{"source": "Core Competencies1.txt", "text": "2. NACADA\u2019s Core Values of Academic Advising.  3. Theory relevant to academic advising. 4. Academic advising approaches and strategies. 5. Expected outcomes of academic advising. 6. How equitable and inclusive environments are created and maintained. \nCore competencies in the Informational component (knowledge academic advisors must master) include knowledge of:  \n1. Institution specific history, mission, vision, values, and culture.  ", "lemma": "NACADA\u2019s Core Values Academic Advising. Theory relevant academic advising. Academic advise approach strategies. Expected outcome academic advising. How equitable inclusive environment be create maintained. Core competency Informational component (knowledge academic advisor master) include knowledge Institution specific history, mission, vision, values, culture."}
{"source": "Core Competencies1.txt", "text": "2. Curriculum, degree programs, and other academic requirements and options.  3. Institution specific policies, procedures, rules, and regulations. 4. Legal guidelines of advising practice, including privacy regulations and confidentiality. 5. The characteristics, needs, and experiences of major and emerging student populations.  6. Campus and community resources that support student success. 7. Information technology applicable to relevant advising roles.  \nCore Competencies in the Relational component (skills academic advisors must demonstrate) include the ability to:\n1. Articulate a personal philosophy of academic advising.  2. Create rapport and build academic advising relationships.  3. Communicate in an inclusive and respectful manner. 4. Plan and conduct successful advising interactions.5. Promote student understanding of the logic and purpose of the curriculum.6. {"source": "Core Values0.txt", "text": "Academic advisors honor the inherent value \nof all students.  Advisors build positive \nrelationships by understanding and \nappreciating students\u2019 views and \ncultures, maintaining a \nstudent-centered approach and \nmindset, and treating students \nwith sensitivity and \nfairness.\nAcademic advisors respect, engage, and value \na supportive culture for diverse populations.  \nAdvisors strive to create and support \nenvironments that consider the needs \nand perspectives of students, \ninstitutions, and colleagues \nthrough openness, \nacceptance, and equity.Academic advisors act in accordance with \nthe values of the profession of \nadvising for the greater good of \nstudents, colleagues, \ninstitutions, and higher \neducation in general.\nAcademic advisors act intentionally in \naccordance with ethical and professional \nbehavior developed through reflective \npractice. Advisors value honesty, \ntransparency, and accountability \nto the student, institution, and \nthe advising profession.\nAcademic advisors respond to and are \naccessible to others in ways that \nchallenge, support, nurture, and teach. \nAdvisors build relationships through \nempathetic listening and \ncompassion for students, \ncolleagues, and others.Academic advisors motivate, encourage, \nand support students and the greater \neducational community to recognize \ntheir potential, meet challenges, \nand respect and express \nindividuality.\nAcademic advisors value and are dedicated to \nexcellence in all dimensions of student \nsuccess. {"source": "Core Values0.txt", "text": "Advisors are committed to \nstudents, colleagues, institutions, and \nthe profession through assessment, \nscholarly inquiry, life-long \nlearning, and professional \ndevelopment.\nThe NACADA Statement of \nCore Values reflects the \nmany cultural and \neducational contexts in which \nacademic advising is practiced globally. A \ndiverse, globally represented task force in \nconjunction with the input of NACADA members contributed to the creation of the \nstatement. By virtue of this process, this \ndocument represents the Core Values of the \nacademic advising profession as a whole. \nThese values apply to all who perform \nacademic advising by any role, title, or \nposition as educators at their institutions.While nations, institutions, and \nstudents will offer unique \ncircumstances, the Core \nValues provide guidance to \nacademic advisors in their professional lives. Academic advisors are committed to \nthe students they advise, their institutions, their professional practice, and the broader \nadvising and educational community. There \nmay be times when balancing all Core \nValues equally is not possible. In those \ninstances, academic advisors are \nencouraged to reflect and engage other \nacademic advising professionals in a \ndialogue to resolve any conflict to the best of their ability.The Statement of Core Values is \nreviewed periodically to ensure \nits alignment with current \nprofessional practices, \ncompetencies, and philosophies. \nNACADA: The Global Community for \nAcademic Advising encourages institutions to \nadopt the Statement of Core Values and support the work of those who provide \nacademic advising.\n", "lemma": "Advisors be commit students, colleagues, institutions, profession assessment, scholarly inquiry, life-long learning, professional development. NACADA Statement Core Values reflect many cultural educational context academic advising be practice A diverse, globally represent task force conjunction input NACADA member contribute creation statement. virtue process, document represent Core Values academic advise profession whole. value apply perform academic advising role, title, position educator institutions.While nations, institutions, student offer unique circumstances, Core Values provide guidance academic advisor professional lives. Academic advisor be commit student advise, institutions, professional practice, broad advising educational community. be time balance Core Values equally be not possible. instances, academic advisor be encourage reflect engage other academic advise professional dialogue resolve conflict best ability.The Statement Core Values be review periodically ensure alignment current professional practices, competencies, philosophies. NACADA: Global Community Academic Advising encourage institution adopt Statement Core Values support work provide academic advising."}
{"source": "Deaf%20and%20Hard%20of%20Hearing%20Guidance%20and%20Informat0.txt", "text": "This guidance and infor mation page is a quick reference tool.  ", "lemma": "guidance infor mation page be quick reference tool."}
{"source": "Deaf%20and%20Hard%20of%20Hearing%20Guidance%20and%20Informat0.txt", "text": "Deaf and Hard of Hearing are  complex di sabilities  and for \nmore comprehensive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nDeaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Information  \nThe definition of deafness  from the  IDEA is a hearing impairment that is so severe that the child is impaired in \nprocessing linguistic information through hearing, with or without amplification.   The definition of hearing \nimpairment is an impairment in hearing, whether permanent or fluctuating, that adversely affects a child\u2019s \neducational performance but that is not included under the definition of \ndeafness .  https://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/b/a/300.8/c/5   \n \n\u2022 Ways of communicating may vary for individuals that are deaf \nor hard of hearing (speech only, sign language, fingerspelling, \nlip reading, writing/reading , with an interpreter,  captioning, or \nany combination)   \n\u2022 Interpreters generally can only capture 50 -60% of oral lectures \nso multiply means of relaying content is needed  \n  \n \n\u2022 Deaf or hard of hearing students generally may sit near the \nfront of the classroom  \n\u2022 Watching in tently and trying to capture course information is \nexhausting   \n\u2022 Socially it can be isolating to be deaf or hard of hearing  \n \n \n \n \n\u2022 The deaf or hard of hearing student is trying to capture all the \ncourse components that others can hear\n", "lemma": "Deaf Hard Hearing be complex di sabilities more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. Deaf Hard Hearing Guidance Information definition deafness IDEA be hearing impairment be so severe child be impair process linguistic information hearing, definition hear impairment be impairment hearing, permanent fluctuating, adversely affect child\u2019s educational performance be not include definition deafness https://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/b/a/300.8/c/5 \u2022 Ways communicating vary individual be deaf hard hear (speech only, sign language, fingerspelling, lip reading, writing/reading interpreter, captioning, combination) \u2022 Interpreters generally only capture -60% oral lecture so multiply mean relay content be need \u2022 Deaf hard hear student generally sit front classroom \u2022 Watching tently try capture course information be exhaust \u2022 Socially be isolate be deaf hard hear deaf hard hear student be try capture course component others hear"}
{"source": "Deaf%20and%20Hard%20of%20Hearing%20Guidance%20and%20Informat1.txt", "text": "This guidance and infor mation page is a quick reference tool.  Deaf and Hard of Hearing are  complex di sabilities  and for \nmore comprehensive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nDeaf and Hard of Hearing  Guidance and Information :  Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Be accepting of how the student communicates  \n\u2022 Support multiple means of capturing the lecture /lab \n\u2022 Be sure to have the  student 's attention before speaking  \n\u2022 Speak or rephrase what you have said facing the student  \n\u2022 Speak slowly and clearly  \n\u2022 Speak directly to the student and not the interpreter  \n\u2022 Student have an amplifying device to be used by the professor or at \nthe front of the classroom  \n \n\u2022 May need to sit near th e front to see the professor speak and read \nexpressions  \n\u2022 May need to sit so they can see an interpreter that may be located \nnear the professor  \n\u2022 May need alerting if there is an audible fire drill or alarm  \n\u2022 Student and interpreter m ay need additional breaks  \n\u2022 May need support with cooperative pairings  \n \n\u2022 Printed materials, procedure s, due dates and timelines  are \nsupportive  \n\u2022 Providing Power Point slides or notes prior to class to the student \nand/or the interpreter is supportive  and proactive  \n\u2022 Assigned, online, or in -class videos should be captioned (work with \nLearning and Technology  ahead of time to support captioning)   \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are helpful  \nResources and References:  \nNational Deaf Center (NDC) https://www.nationaldeafcenter.org/   \nNational Association of the Deaf (NAD)  https://www.nad.org/  \nUS Department of Justice. (2020) ADA requirements:  Effective communications  https://www.ada.gov/effective -comm.htm  \nWestern Region Outreach Center & Consortia at The National Center on Deafness (2020)  Guide to working with deaf and hard of \nhearing students . ", "lemma": "guidance infor mation page be quick reference tool. Deaf Hard Hearing be complex di sabilities more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. Deaf Hard Hearing Guidance Information Support Strategies \u2022 Be accept student communicate \u2022 Support multiple mean capture lecture /lab \u2022 Be sure have student attention speak \u2022 Speak rephrase have say face student \u2022 Speak slowly clearly \u2022 Speak directly student not interpreter \u2022 Student have amplifying device be use professor front classroom \u2022 May need sit th e front see professor speak read expression \u2022 May need sit see interpreter be locate professor \u2022 May need alert be audible fire drill alarm Student interpreter m ay need additional break \u2022 May need support cooperative pairing \u2022 Printed materials, procedure s, due date timeline be supportive \u2022 Providing Power Point slide note prior class student and/or interpreter be supportive proactive \u2022 Assigned, online, -class video be caption (work Learning Technology ahead time support captioning) \u2022 Positive feedback frequent check -ins be helpful Resources References: National Deaf Center (NDC) https://www.nationaldeafcenter.org/ National Association Deaf (NAD) https://www.nad.org/ US Department Justice. (2020) ADA requirements: Effective communication https://www.ada.gov/effective -comm.htm Western Region Outreach Center Consortia National Center Deafness (2020) Guide work deaf hard hear student"}
