{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet0.txt", "text": "Effortless Advising: A Tip Sheet  \nEffortless State  \nAn effortless state is \u201cone in which you are physically rested, emotionally unburdened, and mentally           \nenergized. You are completely present, attentive, and focused on what \u2019s important in that moment.  ", "lemma": "Effortless Advising: A Tip Sheet Effortless State effortless state be be physically rested, emotionally unburdened, mentally energized. be completely present, attentive, focus \u2019s important moment."}
{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet0.txt", "text": "You are \nable to do what matters most with ease \u201d (McKeown, 2021, p. 26).   \n \nENJOY : Flip the script from \u201cadvising is a burden \u201d to \u201cadvising is enjoyable. \u201d Consider the things you enjoy \nand do those in preparation of or during your advising meetings. If you enjoy being outdoors, have your  \nmeetings outdoors.  If you enjoy coffee, make a trip to Beanie \u2019s ahead of time or meet your students in the \nUnion.   \n \nREST : We talk about advising week, but that doesn \u2019t have to be taken literally. Consider extending your \nmeetings into registration week. Freshmen won \u2019t register until the end of the week, so you have more time to \nspace out your meetings. Consider schedule meetings before lunch or before the end of the day so that there \nare built in breaks.  \n \nNOTICE : Active listening is one of the most important aspects of advising. Consider a device -free and         \ndistraction -free environment that allows you to have meaningful face -to-face conversations. Change the     \nenvironment and the timing as needed.  This gets to the core of Appreciative Advising.  \nEffortless Action  \nWith effortless action, \u201cthe goal is to accomplish what matters by trying less, not more: to achieve our purpose \nwith bridled intention, not overexertion \u201d (McKeown, 2021, p. 98).  \n \n", "lemma": "be able do matter most ease \u201d (McKeown, p. ENJOY Flip script \u201cadvising be burden \u201d \u201cadvising be enjoyable. \u201d Consider thing enjoy do preparation advise meetings. enjoy be outdoors, have meeting enjoy coffee, make trip Beanie \u2019s ahead time meet student Union. REST talk advise week, doesn \u2019t have be take literally. Consider extend meeting registration Freshmen win \u2019t register end week, so have more time space out meetings. Consider schedule meeting lunch end day be build breaks. NOTICE Active listening be most important aspect advising. Consider device -free distraction -free environment allow have meaningful face -to-face conversations. Change environment timing needed. get core Appreciative Advising. Effortless Action effortless action, \u201cthe goal be accomplish matter try less, not more: achieve purpose bridled intention, not overexertion \u201d (McKeown, p."}
{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet0.txt", "text": "DEFINE : Determine what done looks like.  For a student who attends an advising meeting, perhaps done   \noccurs after a synchronous meeting, where academic progress and concerns are discussed, a proposed \nschedule is reviewed, and a PIN is delivered.  For a student who does not attend, perhaps done occurs after \none reminder email.  \n \nSIMPLIFY : Fewer steps = less effort.  Consider extra steps you may be taking that aren \u2019t necessary.  For  \nexample, if you routinely show students online resources, have the students open their laptops and navigate.  \nOr consider having your advisees send you a PDF of their transcript before their meeting rather than you \nlooking up the information.  \n \nPROGRESS : Every advising meeting is a learning opportunity.  Consider keeping notes so that you can  \nidentify what went well and what could be improved.  Remember, even Bobby Flay, Mark Rober, and Serena \nWilliams weren \u2019t always the people we now know.\n", "lemma": "DEFINE Determine do look like. student attend advise meeting, perhaps do occurs synchronous meeting, academic progress concern be discussed, propose schedule be reviewed, PIN be delivered. student do not attend, perhaps do occurs reminder email. SIMPLIFY Fewer step = less effort. Consider extra step be take aren \u2019t necessary. example, routinely show student online resources, have student open laptop navigate. Or consider have advisee send PDF transcript meeting rather look up information. PROGRESS advise meeting be learning opportunity. Consider keep note identify go well be improved. Remember, even Bobby Flay, Mark Rober, Serena Williams weren \u2019t always people now know."}
{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet1.txt", "text": "For effortless results, \u201cexert effort once and reap the benefits again and again.  Results continue to flow to \nyou, whether you put in additional effort or not \u201d (McKeown, 2021, p. 149).  \n \nAUTOMATE : There are many tasks we do repeatedly.  Consider ways to automate these tasks.  For          \nexample, document recurring email responses so that you can copy/paste in the future.  Bookmark any My \nRose -Hulman pages or any other websites you reference often in order to reduce the number of clicks.  \n \nTRUST :  Trust is essential in an advising relationship, and high -trust relationships require less overall effort.        \nConsider establishing clear roles (\u201cAs the advisor, I will do this; as the advisee, you should do that \u201d) and     \nexpectations (e.g., how to schedule a meeting; what to prepare ahead of time; consequences for not meeting \nexpectations).  This might also include sharing tips and highlighting resources available to help with tasks.  \n \nPREVENT : To reduce frustration, try to solve problems before they happen.  Consider using the scheduler \nactivity in your Moodle course to schedule appointments.  Not only will this reduce the number of back -and-\nforth emails, but the scheduler activity can send reminders to students.  You can set up a reminder of the   \nappointment (from the morning of, to several days out); you can even quickly send a reminder email to those \nwho have not yet scheduled their meeting.  \nYour turn! ", "lemma": "effortless results, \u201cexert effort once reap benefit again again. Results continue flow you, put additional effort not \u201d p. AUTOMATE be many task do repeatedly. Consider way automate tasks. example, document recur email response so copy/paste future. Bookmark My Rose -Hulman page other website reference often order reduce number clicks. TRUST Trust be essential advising relationship, high -trust relationship require less overall effort. Consider establish clear role (\u201cAs advisor, do this; advisee, do \u201d) expectation (e.g., schedule meeting; prepare ahead time; consequence not meet expectations). also include share tip highlight resource available help tasks. PREVENT reduce frustration, try solve problem happen. Consider use scheduler activity Moodle course schedule appointments. Not only reduce number back -and- forth emails, scheduler activity send reminder students. set up reminder appointment morning of, several day even quickly send reminder email have not yet schedule meeting. turn!"}

{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet1.txt", "text": "90).  \nRELEASE  \n\u201cLet go of emotional burdens \u201d \nand \u201crelieve a grudge of its \nduties by asking, \u2019What job \nhave I hired this grudge to \ndo?\u2019\u201d (p. 90).  START   \n\u201cMake the first action the \nmost obvious one. Break the \nfirst obvious action down into \nthe tiniest, concrete step \u201d (p. \n143).  \nPACE   \n\u201cSet an effortless pace: slow \nis smooth, smooth is fast. \nReject the false economy of \n\u2018powering through \u2019\u201d (p. 144). Under-\nstand first principles deeply \nand then apply them again \nand again \u201d (p. 205).  \nLIFT   \n\u201cAchieve far -reaching impact \nby teaching others to teach.  \nTell stories that are easily \nunderstood and repeated \u201d (p. \n170).\n", "lemma": "RELEASE \u201cLet go emotional burden \u201d \u201crelieve grudge duty asking, job have hire grudge do?\u2019\u201d (p. {"source": "FERPA Exceptions2.txt", "text": "34 CFR \u00a7\u00a7 99.31(a)(1) and 99.7(a)(3)(iii).  34 CFR \u00a7 99.31(a) (6). 34 CFR \u00a7\u00a7 99.31(a)(3) and 99.35.  \nOther notes  \nRecord\nation: FERPA does not \nrequire educational agencies and institutions to reco rd \ndisclosures of appropriately \ndesignated directory \ninformation (\u00a7 99.32(d)(4)).  Recordation : FERPA \n(\u00a7 99.32(d)(2)) does not require \neducational agencies and \ninstitutions to record disclosures of PII from \neducation records to school officials under \u00a7 99.31(a)(1).  Recordation : FERPA requires \neducational agencies and \ninstitutions to record all \ndisclosures of PII from education records to \norganizations made under the \nstudies exception (\u00a7 99.32).   Recordation : FERPA requires educational agencies and \ninstitutions to record all disclosures of PII from education \nrecords made under the audit or evaluation exception \n(\u00a7 99.32).  \n\uf0d8State and local educational authorities (and other\nFERPA -permitted entities listed in \u00a7 99.31(a)(3))\nredisclosing PII on behalf of the educational agency\nor institution must record disclosures according to the\nrequirements in \u00a7 99.32(b)(2).\nSee\t\r \u00a0PTAC\t\r \u00a0website\t\r \u00a0for\t\r \u00a0Additional\t\r \u00a0Resources\t\r \u00a0and\t\r \u00a0Glossary:\t\r \u00a0 http://ptac.ed.gov \t\r \u00a0\nPTAC-Handout-2H, April 2014 \t\r \u00a0\nhttp://ptac.ed.gov\n", "lemma": "CFR \u00a7\u00a7 CFR \u00a7 (6). CFR \u00a7\u00a7 Other note Record ation: FERPA do not require educational agency institution reco rd disclosure appropriately designate directory information Recordation FERPA (\u00a7 do not require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record school official \u00a7 Recordation FERPA require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record organization make study exception Recordation FERPA require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record make audit evaluation exception (\u00a7 \uf0d8State local educational authority (and other FERPA -permitted entity list \u00a7 redisclosing PII behalf educational agency institution record disclosure accord requirement \u00a7 See PTAC website Additional Resources Glossary: http://ptac.ed.gov PTAC-Handout-2H, April http://ptac.ed.gov"}
{"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout0.txt", "text": "The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)  1974  \nWhat is FERPA?  \n\uf0b7 Provides students with rights pertaining to  their education records  \n\uf0b7 Enforced by the Family Policy Compliance Office (FCPO) at the  U.S. Dept  of Education  \n\uf0b7 Provides penalties up to and including the loss of Department of Education funds for \ninstitutions that have a policy or practice of violating FERPA   \nWho must comply with FERPA?  \n\uf0b7 All schools that receive Dept  of Education  funding, i ncluding student financial aid \nWhat are considered education records?  \n\uf0b7 Any records \u201cdirectly rel ated to a student\u201d maintained by the school or a party acting for \nthe school  such as contractors or vendors  \nWhat records are not education records under FERPA?  \n\uf0b7 Any information th at is not a maintained record  \n\uf0b7 Personal knowledge and observations of professors, staff, and other educational \nemployees  for which no record is created  \n\uf0b7 Records created for a law enforcement purpose s and maintained by a school\u2019s law \nenfo rcement unit  \n\uf0b7 Medical treatment records at colleges and universities as long as they are:  \no Made and maint ained by a medical professional  \no Used only in the co urse of providing treatment  \no Disclosed only to individuals providing treatment  \nNOTE:  FERPA does not prevent the sharing of medical re cords with school officials, but \ndoing so would make them education records.   \n\uf0b7 Alumni records if they are  created or received by a school after an individual no longer \nattends the school and not directly related to the individuals\u2019 attendance as a student  \n\uf0b7 Employee records,  unless they are students who  have to be students t o have the job  \nWhat rights does FERPA provide?  \n", "lemma": "Family Educational Rights Privacy Act (FERPA) be FERPA? \uf0b7 Provides student right pertain education record \uf0b7 Enforced Family Policy Compliance Office (FCPO) U.S. Dept Education \uf0b7 Provides penalties include loss Department Education fund institution have policy practice violate FERPA Who comply FERPA? \uf0b7 All school receive Dept Education funding, i ncluding student financial aid be consider education records? \uf0b7 record \u201cdirectly rel ated student\u201d maintain school party act school such contractor vendor record be not education record FERPA? \uf0b7 Any information th be not maintain record \uf0b7 Personal knowledge observation professors, staff, other educational employee record be create \uf0b7 Records create law enforcement purpose s maintain school\u2019s law rcement unit \uf0b7 Medical treatment record college university as long are: o Made maint ained medical professional o Used only co urse provide treatment o Disclosed only individual provide treatment NOTE: FERPA do not prevent sharing medical re cord school officials, do so make education records. \uf0b7 Alumni record be create receive school individual no longer attend school not directly relate individuals\u2019 attendance student \uf0b7 Employee records, be student have be student t o have job right do FERPA provide?"}
{"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout0.txt", "text": "\uf0b7 Students must be notified of their FERPA rights at least annually  \n\uf0b7 Students have a right to inspect and review their records  \n\uf0b7 Students have a right to amend an incorrect record  \n\uf0b7 Students have a right to have their records disc losed only with their consent, unless an \nexception applies  \n\uf0b7 Students have a right to file a complaint with the Department of Education  \nWhat is required for compliance?  \n\uf0b7 Instit utions must annually notify students of their rights under FERPA  which includes:\n", "lemma": "\uf0b7 Students be notify FERPA right least annually \uf0b7 Students have right inspect review record Students have right amend incorrect record \uf0b7 Students have right have record disc lose only consent, exception applies \uf0b7 Students have right file complaint Department Education be require compliance? \uf0b7 Instit utions annually notify student right FERPA includes:"}
{"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout1.txt", "text": "o Their rights to inspect and review records and seek  to amend or correct a record  \no The school\u2019s procedures for students to exercise their rights to access their re cords \nand requ est corrections  \no Their right to file a complaint with t he U.S. Department of Education  \no A statement that education records may be disclosed to school officials with \nlegitimate educational interests without the written consent of the student  \no The criteria for determining who constitutes a school official and what constitutes a \nlegitimate educational interest  \n\uf0b7 Schools must allow students access to their reco rds within 45 days upon request  \n\uf0b7 Schools must provide students with an opportunity to challenge and amend po rtion of \nan education record that students consider to be inaccurate, misleading, or otherwise in \nviolation of their privacy or other rights  \no If the record in question is amendable under FERPA , then a student who is not \nprovided the full relief is entitled to a formal hearing on the matter  \no If a school does  not agree with a student\u2019s request to amend the record, the \nstudent must be given an opportunity to pl ace a statement into the record  \nWhen ca n education records be disclosed?  \n\uf0b7 As a general rule, FERPA requires that education records be kept confidential and that to \ndisclose them to a third party, a student must provide written consent containing:  \no Date and student\u2019s signature  \no Purpose of the discl osure  \no Specify w hat records are to be disclosed  \no Identity of party  or class of parties to whom the disclosure may be made  \nNOTE: Written consent is not needed when students request to se e their own education \nrecords; h owever, schools must reasonably  auth enticate the student\u2019s identity  \n\uf0b7 Exceptions that permit records to be disclosed without  a student\u2019s consent:  \no To school officials with legitimate educational interests . {"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout1.txt", "text": "School officials may include : \n\uf0a7 Students serving on a disciplinary committee  \n\uf0a7 Security or custodial staff  \n\uf0a7 Outside contractors performing school functions or other service providers \nif they are under the direct control of the school  \nNOTE: For a legitimate educational interest to exist, the information must \nbe necessary for the school official to perform job -related tasks (such as \ntasks related to a student\u2019s education or discipline, to provide student \nservices such as financial aid, c ounseling, job placement, etc.)\n", "lemma": "School official include \uf0a7 Students serve disciplinary committee \uf0a7 Security custodial staff \uf0a7 Outside contractor perform school function other service provider be direct control school NOTE: legitimate educational interest exist, information be necessary school official perform job -related task (such task relate student\u2019s education discipline, provide student service such financial aid, c ounseling, job placement, etc.)"}
{"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout2.txt", "text": "o Disciplinary records are covered by FERPA and may not be generally disclosed \nwithout the student\u2019s consent.  However, institutions of higher education are \nallowed to disclose to an alleged victim of a crime of violence the f inal results of a \ndisciplinary proceeding against the alleged perpetrator of the crime, regardless of \nwhether the institution concluded a violation was committed.  If a school \ndetermines that a student is the perpetrator of a crime of violence this \ndetermi nation may be released to anyone.  \no In a heal th or safety emergency.  If school officials have identified \u201can articulable \nand significant threat to the health or safety of the student or other individuals,\u201d \nthey can disclose student information to anyone necessary to address the \nsituation.  \no An institution may disclose a student\u2019s records to the student\u2019s parents wit hout \nconsent if the student is claimed as a dependent fo r federal income tax purposes.  \no Parents can also see a students records if the student is  under 21 years old and \nhas been found in violation of the institution\u2019g drug or alcohol policy.  \no Schools can disclose student information without consent when a  student is \ntransferring, or in connection with financial aid.  \no Schools can disclose \u201cdirectory i nformation\u201d without consent provided they allow \neligible students a right to opt out.  Items that may be designated as directory \ninformation include:  \n\uf0a7 Name  \n\uf0a7 Address  \n\uf0a7 Date of Birth  \n\uf0a7 Photograph  \n\uf0a7 Phone number  \n\uf0a7 Most recent school attended  \uf0a7 Participatio n in official  \nactivities and sports  \n\uf0a7 Weight and height of \nmembers of athletic teams  \n\uf0a7 Degrees and awards  \nreceived\no Certain types of sensitive personal information can never be deemed directory \ninformation.  This includes information such as: \n\uf0a7 Race  \n\uf0a7 Gender  \n\uf0a7 Grades  \n\uf0a7 GPA  \uf0a7 Any part of a social security \nnumber  \n\uf0a7 Country of citizenship  \n\uf0a7 Religion  \nNOTE: Schools must notify  students of the information classified as directory \ninformation and allow them to opt out of the d isclosure.  \nHow does FERPA work with stat e laws?   \n", "lemma": "o Disciplinary record be cover FERPA not be generally disclose student\u2019s consent. However, institution high education be allow disclose allege victim crime violence f inal result disciplinary proceeding alleged perpetrator crime, regardless institution conclude violation be committed. school determine student be perpetrator crime violence determi nation be release anyone. o heal th safety emergency. school official have identify \u201can articulable significant threat health safety student other individuals,\u201d disclose student information anyone necessary address situation. o institution disclose student\u2019s record student\u2019s parent wit hout consent student be claim dependent fo r federal income tax purposes. Parents also see student record student be year old have be find violation institution\u2019g drug alcohol policy. Schools disclose student information consent student be transferring, connection financial aid. o Schools disclose \u201cdirectory i nformation\u201d consent provide allow eligible student right opt out. Items be designate directory information include: \uf0a7 Name \uf0a7 Address \uf0a7 Date Birth \uf0a7 Photograph \uf0a7 Phone number \uf0a7 Most recent school attend \uf0a7 Participatio n official activity sport \uf0a7 Weight height member athletic team \uf0a7 Degrees award receive o Certain type sensitive personal information never be deem directory information. include information such as: \uf0a7 Race \uf0a7 Gender \uf0a7 Grades \uf0a7 GPA \uf0a7 Any part social security number \uf0a7 Country citizenship \uf0a7 Religion NOTE: Schools notify student information classify directory information allow opt d isclosure. {"source": "FERPA Questions and Answers Handout2.txt", "text": "\uf0b7 General rule of thumb: If FERPA has a \u201cmust\u201d rule, follow FERPA.  If FERPA has a \u201cmay\u201d \nrule, follow state law.  However, schools should consult with the FPCO whenever there \nis any perceived conflict between a state open records law and FERPA.\n", "lemma": "\uf0b7 General rule thumb: FERPA have \u201cmust\u201d rule, follow FERPA. ", "lemma": "NEW HSSA GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS Approved February Goals: \u2022 Make student HSSA course choice more meaningful flexible \u2022 Improve clarity course designati ons graduation requirement \u2022 Simplify transfer credit, incoming outgo \u2022 Make visible distinction HSSA discipline \u2022 Increase readability student transcript New System Courses categorie s be label list disciplinary prefix a. Humanities Arts (H) b. Social Sciences (S) c. Modern Languages (L) Humanities Arts Social Sciences Modern Languages ARTS ANTH GER ENGL ECON JAPN HIST GEOG SPAN MUSI POLS PHIL PSYC RELG SOC* HUM* * Catch -all category interdisciplinary/unique course offering"}

Students must take a course in at least two categories . The following features of \nthe current requirements  remain:  \na. Students must take 9 courses  (including RH courses)  \nb. RH/writing  courses (131, 330) do not count as H, S, or L  \nc. Students who take the introductory/111 course  of a language  alone cannot \ncount  the course toward HSSA  requirements  \nd. Once the schedule has \nbeen published you will be able to create up to 5 registration plans.  You can register from these saved plans when they \nare created with course sections (CRNs).   \n \nCreate a Registration Plan \n\uf0b7 Select Create Registration Plans from the main registration menu. \n \n \n \n", "lemma": "Register Plan Students create multiple Registration Plans Banner prior opening registration. schedule have be publish be able create up registration register save plan be create course section (CRNs). Create Registration Plan \uf0b7 Select Create Registration Plans main registration menu."}
{"source": "How to Register from a Plan0.txt", "text": "\uf0b7 Select the term you are going to register for, then you will be presented with an option to create a new plan. \nSelect the Create a New Plan  button to add sections to your Degree Works plan OR to create a new Registration \nPlan in Banner.  You will only see the Degree Works option if you have a plan in Degree Works that has been \napproved by your advisor. \n \n\uf0b7 If you have a Degree Works plan, click on the Degree Works Plans tab.  Your planned courses will be displayed. \n \n \n \n\uf0b7 If you do not have a Degree Works plan, add courses individually using the Find Courses tab.\n", "lemma": "\uf0b7 Select term be go register for, then be present option create new plan. Continue to add courses to the plan \nuntil you have built your full schedule. \n              ", "lemma": "\uf0b7 Using method, now be able add section plan course select View Sections buttons. {"source": "How to Register from a Plan3.txt", "text": "\uf0b7 If you have schedule errors, hitting submit again will remove the course if the drop-down option is REMOVE.   \n\uf0b7 If there is no error, but the class is full AND a waitlist is available for the section, you will be able select the \nwaitlist option from the drop down and hit submit again. \n\uf0b7 You can now make further schedule changes as needed.\n", "lemma": "\uf0b7 have schedule hit submit again remove course drop-down option be REMOVE. \uf0b7 be error, class be full waitlist be available section, be able select waitlist option drop down hit submit now make further schedule change needed."}

{"source": "Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet0.txt", "text": "Learning Disabilities are complex and diverse  and for more \ncomprehensive information please use the references provided or conta ct Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nLearning Disability  Guidance and Information  \nThe Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) defines a  Specific Learning \nDisability  (SLD) as \u201ca disorder in one or more of the basic psychological processes involved in \nunderstanding or in using language, spoken or written, that may manifest itself in the \nimperfect ability to listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, or to do mathematical \ncalcu lations.\u201d SLD is the most common category under IDEA. Categories of SLD include \ndyslexia, dysgraphia, dyscalculia, auditory processing disorde r, and nonverbal learning \ndisability.    https://www.understood.org/en/school -learning/special -services/special -\neducation -basics/conditions -covered -under -idea   \n \n\u2022 May prefer face to face communication with faculty and/or \ncollaborative gr oups  \n\u2022 May struggle to read handwriting and/or printed \nmaterial/email  \n\u2022 Verbal r esponse may be delayed due to auditory processing    \n \n\u2022 May have visual/spatial challenges  \n\u2022 May have difficulty with handwriting and note taking  \n\u2022 May have an auditory processing delay   \n\u2022 May have difficulty transferring writing from the board to \npaper  \n \n \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty organizing school assignments  \n\u2022 May take longer to complete written work  \n\u2022 May miss verbal directions due  an auditory processing delay  \n\u2022 In general, it takes a few days to set up in -class note takers and \nelectronic text versions at the beginning of a quarter\n", "lemma": "Learning Disabilities be complex diverse more comprehensive information please use reference provide conta ct Student Accessibility Services. Learning Disability Guidance Information Individuals Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) define Specific Learning Disability (SLD) \u201ca disorder more basic psychological process involve understand use language, spoken written, manifest imperfect ability listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, do mathematical calcu lations.\u201d SLD be most common category IDEA. Categories SLD include dyslexia, dysgraphia, dyscalculia, auditory processing disorde r, nonverbal learning disability. https://www.understood.org/en/school -learning/special -services/special education -basics/conditions -covered -under -idea \u2022 May prefer face face communication faculty and/or collaborative gr oups \u2022 May struggle read handwrite and/or print material/email \u2022 Verbal r esponse be delay due auditory processing \u2022 May have visual/spatial challenge \u2022 May have difficulty handwriting note take \u2022 May have auditory processing delay \u2022 May have difficulty transfer write board paper \u2022 May have difficulty organize school assignment \u2022 May take long complete write work \u2022 May miss verbal direction due auditory processing delay \u2022 general, take few day set up -class note taker electronic text version beginning quarter"}
{"source": "Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet1.txt", "text": "This guidance and information page is a quick reference tool.  Learning Disabilities are complex and diverse  and for more \ncomprehensive information please use the references provided or conta ct Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nLearning Disability Guidance and Information :  Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Provide verbal as well as  electronically printed  due dates  and \ndirections  \n\u2022 Provide pdf or word documents electronically with  non-serif font to \nsupport reading software   \n\u2022 Understand that meeting face to face or on Teams with faculty \nand/or collaborative groups  may be preferred to email  \n \n\u2022 Understand  that handwriting  and/or audio processing may be \nimpacted and supports such as audio recording to capture lecture \nnotes to play  back  or copies of notes  are supportive  \n\u2022 The ability to use a laptop keyboard to word process notes/longer \nwritten tests or assignments is supporti ve when students have \ndysgraphia  \n \n\u2022 Textbooks with an alternative electronic format to support reading \nsoftware (Accesstext, Bookshare, and larger publishing companies \nprovide this when the student has purchased a text)  \n\u2022 Speech to Text software to support writing  \n\u2022 Text to speech software to read electronic notes, textbooks  \n\u2022 Most written work simply takes more time for a student with SLD  \n\u2022 Be supportive of timeframe to set up accommodations  \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are  helpful  \nResources a nd References:  \nNational Center for Learning Disabilities https://www.ncld.org/   \nCouncil for Learning Disabilities https://council -for-learning -disabilities.org/   \nCouncil for Learning Disabilities. (2016) College: A realistic option for students with learning disabilities.  ", "lemma": "guidance information page be quick reference tool. Learning Disabilities be complex diverse more comprehensive information please use reference provide conta ct Student Accessibility Services. Learning Disability Guidance Information Support Strategies \u2022 Provide verbal as well electronically print due date direction \u2022 Provide pdf word document electronically non-serif font support read software \u2022 Understand meet face face Teams faculty and/or collaborative group be prefer email \u2022 Understand handwrite and/or audio processing be impact support such audio recording capture lecture note play back copy note be supportive ability use laptop keyboard word process notes/longer write test assignment be supporti ve student have dysgraphia \u2022 Textbooks alternative electronic format support read software (Accesstext, Bookshare, large publishing company provide student have purchase text) \u2022 Speech Text software support write \u2022 Text speech software read electronic notes, textbooks \u2022 Most write work simply take more time student SLD \u2022 Be supportive timeframe set up accommodation \u2022 Positive feedback frequent check -ins be helpful Resources nd References: National Center Learning Disabilities https://www.ncld.org/ Council Learning Disabilities https://council -for-learning -disabilities.org/ Council Learning Disabilities. (2016) College: A realistic option student learn disabilities."}

"\u25cf\nInvited\nstudents\ncan\nselect\neither\nMA105/106/107\nor\nMA111/112.\nIf\na\nstudent\nremains\nundecided\nat\nthe\ntime\nof\nadvisement,\nthen\nplease\ndiscuss\nwhich\nsequence\nwould\nbe\nbest\nfor\nyour\nadvisee.\n\u25cb\nIf\na\nstudent\nis\nconfident\nin\ntheir\nprecalculus\nbackground\nand\nin\ntheir\nability\nto\nadapt\nto\nthe\npace\nof\na\nfive-hour\ncalculus\ncourse\nat\nRose-Hulman,\nthen\nadvise\nMA111.\nTaking\nMA111\npositions\na\nstudent\nto\ncomplete\ntheir\ncalculus\nsequence\nin\nthe\nSpring\nof\ntheir\nfirst\nyear.\n\u25cb\nIf\na\nstudent\nis\nless\nconfident\nin\ntheir\nprecalculus\nbackground\nor\nin\ntheir\nability\nto\nadapt\nto\nthe\npace\nof\na\nfive-hour\ncalculus\ncourse\nat\nRose-Hulman,\nthen\nadvise\nMA105.\nEntering\nMA105/106/107\nensures\nprecalculus\nreview\nand\na\npace\nsimilar\nto\nthe\nhigh\nschool\nexperience.\nTaking\nMA105/106/107\npositions\na\nstudent\nto\ncomplete\ntheir\ncalculus\nsequence\nin\nthe\nsummer\nafter\ntheir\nfirst\nyear\nor\nin\nthe\nfirst\nquarter\nof\ntheir\nsecond\nyear.\n\u25cb\nIf\nan\ninvited\nstudent\ndecides\nto\ntake\nMA105\nduring\nadvisement,\nthen\ncontact\nthe\nhead\nof\nthe\ndepartment\nof\nmathematics\nto\nhave\nthe\nstudent\nadded\nto\na\nsection\nof\nMA105\nbefore\nregistration.\n\u25cb\nNOTE:\nStudents\nentering\nMA111\nwill\nnot\nbe\nable\nto\nmove\nto\nthe\nMA105/106/107\nsequence\nafter\nthe\ninitial\nadd/drop\nperiod.\nAdditions\nto\nMA105\nare\nrestricted\nby\ncapacity\nand\nby\ninstructor\npermission\nduring\nthe\nadd/drop\nperiod.\n\u25cb\nNOTE:\nThe\npractical\noutcome\nof\nthe\nprevious\ncomment\nis\nthat\nstudents\nwho\nenter\nRose-Hulman\nwithout\ncredit\nfor\nMA111\nwill\nbe\nselecting\neither\nMA105/106/107/113\nor\nMA111/112/113\nas\ntheir\ncalculus\nprogression,\nand\nthat\nthey\nwill\nbe\nmaking\nthis\ndecision\nat\nthe\nbeginning\nof\ntheir\nfirst\nquarter\nat\nRose-Hulman.\nBoth\nsequences\nhave\nbenefits,\nand\ndeciding\nwhich\nwould\nbe\nbest\ndepends\non\na\nstudent\u2019s\npreparation\nand\nmotivation\nand\non\ntheir\ncurricular\ngoals\nat\nRose-Hulman.\n\u25cf\nSeats\nin\nMA105\nnot\naccounted\nfor\nby\nthose\nwho\nhave\nbeen\ninvited\nwill\nbe\navailable\nduring\nregistration\non\na\nfirst-come\nbasis.\nPlease\ndiscuss\nwith\nyour\nadvisees\nthe\nMA105/106/107\noption,\nand\nadvise\nthem\nto\npursue\nthis\nsequence\nduring\nregistration\nif\nthey\nprefer\nit.\nIf\nMA105\nis\nfull,\nthen\na\nstudent\nshould\nremain\nin\nMA111.\nQuestions\n:\nPlease\ndirect\nquestions\nto\nDave\nRader\n(\nrader@rose-hulman.edu\n),\nAl\nHolder\n(\nholder@rose-hulman.edu\n),\nor\nDavid\nFinn\n(\nfinn@rose-hulman.edu\n).\n", Use notes for appointments \u2013 to determine who will be a llowed to see the notes  \ni. {"source": "Orthopedic%20or%20Mobility%20Impairment%20Guidance%20and%20I0.txt", "text": "Orthopedic or Mobility Impairment  Guidance and Information  \nOrthopedic impairment means a severe orthopedic impairment that adversely affects a \nchild\u2019s educational performance. The term includes impairments caused by a congenital \nanomaly, impairments caused by disease (e.g., poliomyelitis, bone tuberculosis), and \nimpairments from other causes (e.g., cerebral palsy, amputations, and fractures or \nburns that cause contractures) Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) \nhttps://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/ b/a/300.8/c/8   \n \n\u2022 Speech may or may not be impacted due to condition   \n\u2022 Verbal r esponse may be delayed due to processing  variances  \n\u2022 Ability to communicate through handwriting may be impacted  \n \n \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty with handwriting and note taking  \n\u2022 May have an auditory processing delay   \n\u2022 May have difficulty transferring writing from the board to \npaper   \n\u2022 May physically need more time and space to move and \ntransition  with or without special equipment  \n\u2022 Small motor tasks may be impacted such as opening a \ncombination lock  \n\u2022 May need accessible pathways  \n \n \n\u2022 May take longer to complete written work  \n\u2022 May miss verbal directions due  an auditory processing delay  \n\u2022 It takes a few days to set up in -class note takers or scribes for \nstudents  with orthopedic impairments\n", "lemma": "Orthopedic Mobility Impairment Guidance Information Orthopedic impairment mean severe orthopedic impairment adversely affect child\u2019s educational performance. term include impairment cause congenital anomaly, impairment cause disease (e.g., poliomyelitis, bone tuberculosis), impairment other cause (e.g., cerebral palsy, amputations, fracture burn cause contractures) Individuals Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) https://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/ b/a/300.8/c/8 \u2022 Speech not be impact due condition \u2022 Verbal r esponse be delay due process variance \u2022 Ability communicate handwriting be impact \u2022 May have difficulty handwriting note take \u2022 May have auditory processing delay \u2022 May have difficulty transfer write board paper \u2022 May physically need more time space move transition special equipment \u2022 Small motor task be impact such open combination lock \u2022 May need accessible pathway \u2022 May take long complete write work \u2022 May miss verbal direction due auditory processing delay \u2022 take few day set up -class note taker scribe student orthopedic impairment"}
{"source": "Orthopedic%20or%20Mobility%20Impairment%20Guidance%20and%20I1.txt", "text": "Orthopedic and Mobility Impairments  are complex and \ndiverse  and for more comprehensive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility \nServices.  \n \n \nOrthopedic or Mobility Impairment Guidance and Information :  Support \nStrategies  \n \n\u2022 Provide verbal as well as  electronically printed  due dates  and \ndirections  \n\u2022 Allow time to respond in verbal conversations  \n\u2022 May use speech augmentation devices   \n \n\u2022 Understand  that handwriting and/or audio processing may be \nimpacted and supports such as audio recording to capture lecture \nnotes to play  back  or copies of notes  are sup portive  \n\u2022 The ability to use a laptop keyboard to word process notes/longer \nwritten tests or assignments is supportive whe n the upper body is \nimpacted  \n\u2022 Provide an equitable alternative to small or large motor tasks as \nneeded  \n \n\u2022 Speech to Text software to supp ort writing   \n\u2022 A scribe may be needed during quizzes or tests  \n\u2022 A peer or teaching assistant may be needed to support fine motor lab \nprocesses  \n\u2022 Most written work simply takes m ore time if the upper body is \nimpacted  \n\u2022 Be supportive of timeframe to set up accommodations  \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are  helpful  \nResources and References:  \nNational Rehabilitation Information Center http://www.naric.com/   \nSpina Bifida Association of America http://www.sbaa.org/    \nUnited Cerebral Palsy Associations, Inc.  www.ucp.org\n", "lemma": "Orthopedic Mobility Impairments be complex diverse more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. {"source": "Psychological Disabilities Guidance and Information0.txt", "text": "Each psychological disorder  is complex and for more \ncomprehensive information please  use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nPsychological Disabilities Guidance and Information  \nPsychological Disabilities at the post -secondary level may include, anxiety, bi -polar disorder, \nborderline personality disorder, depression, obsessive -compulsive disorder, schizophrenia, \npost traumatic stress disorder and others.  Under the revised ADA of 2008 if any of these \nconditions cause a limitation of a life function, they are determined to be a disabilit y  \nhttps://www.ada.gov/  \n \n\u2022 The communication sty le of a student with a psychological \ndisability will vary based on the individual and the condition  \n\u2022 The range of interactions can be verbose to quiet  \n\u2022 May have difficulty sustaining attention  \n\u2022 May have difficulty listening or following verbal directions  \n\u2022 May not appear to be listening  \n \n\u2022 May be fidgety and find it hard to sit still in class  \n\u2022 May display an inner restlessness  \n\u2022 May appear lethargic or sleepy  \n\u2022 May appear to have pervasive unhappiness  \n\u2022 May have poor sleeping patterns  \n\u2022 May appear fragile  \n \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty organizing school assignments  \n\u2022 May struggle to initiate tasks  \n\u2022 May lack attention to detail  \n\u2022 May procrastinate on topics of little interest  \n\u2022 May miss deadlines and due dates  \n\u2022 May be absent from class or lab  \n\u2022 Basic executive function skills may be impacted\n", "lemma": "psychological disorder be complex more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. {"source": "Psychological Disabilities Guidance and Information1.txt", "text": "This guidance and information page is a quick reference tool.  Each psychological disorder  is complex and for more \ncomprehensive information please  use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \n \nPsychological Disabilities  Guidance and Information :  Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Determine how the student prefers communication (face to face, \nTeams, email, scheduled times)  \n\u2022 Use calm tone  \n\u2022 Printed procedure, directions , and due dates are helpful  \n\u2022 Frequent feedback and routine check ins are helpful  \n \n \n\u2022 Allow movement breaks during longer sessions  \n\u2022 Allow the student an exit strategy if they need to leave class  \n\u2022 Headsets or headsets with music or white noise are sometimes \nhelpful when testing  \n \n \n\u2022 Printed due dates , timelines , posted copies of notes  help support the \nstudent when there is lack of organization/lack of sleep  \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are  helpful  \n\u2022 Being calm and consistent is supportive  \n\u2022 Seek help from Student Affairs as ne eded (Residence Life can check \nin on student)  \nResources and References:  \nNational Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) https://nami.org/home   \nNational Behavioral Intervention Team Association (NaBITA)   https://www.nabita.org/  (Rose Cares is a NaBITA team)  \nGuare, D. & Dawson, P. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/ROTC-Air%20Force/as-201.html", "text": "AS 201 - The Evolution of Air and Space Power I\nCredit Hours:2 Term Available: Fall \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: AS 103 or consent of instructor\nCorequisites: None\nThis course designed to examine the general aspects of air and space power through a historical perspective. Utilizing this perspective, the course covers a time period from the first balloons and dirigibles to the space-age global positioning systems of the Persian Gulf War. Historical examples are provided to extrapolate the development of Air Force capabilities (competencies), and missions (functions) to demonstrate the evolution of what has become today's USAF air and space power. Furthermore, the course examines several fundamental truths associated with war in the third dimension: e.g. Principles of War and Tenets of Air and Space Power. As a whole, this course provides the cadets with a knowledge level understanding for the general element and employment of air and space power, from an institutional doctrinal and historical perspective. In addition, the students will continue to discuss the importance of the Air Force Core Values, through the use of operational examples and historical Air Force leaders, and will continue to develop their communication skills. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course by providing cadets with followership experiences.", "lemma": "Evolution Air Space Power Credit Hours:2 Term Available: Fall Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: consent instructor Corequisites: None course design examine general aspect air space power historical perspective. Utilizing perspective, course cover time period first balloon dirigible space-age global position system Persian Gulf War. Historical example be provide extrapolate development Air Force capability (competencies), mission (functions) demonstrate evolution have become today's USAF air space power. Furthermore, course examine several fundamental truth associate war third dimension: e.g. Principles War Tenets Air Space Power. whole, course provide cadet knowledge level understand general element employment air space power, institutional doctrinal historical perspective. addition, student continue discuss importance Air Force Core Values, use operational example historical Air Force leaders, continue develop communication skills. Leadership Laboratory be mandatory AFROTC cadet complement course provide cadet followership experiences."}

{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Biology/bio-352.html", "text": "BIO 352 - Synthetic Biology Laboratory\nCredit Hours: 4 Term Available: Spring u1\nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: Instructor Consent\nCorequisites: None\nOpen to all majors. This project-based studio laboratory course focuses on the fundamental laboratory techniques employed in the synthetic biology laboratory. Relevant background and theory will be discussed and applied in the hands-on learning of core laboratory techniques. In practice, students will build and test novel genetic devices designed to advance the current International Genetically Engineered Machine Competition (iGEM) Team project. Significant contribution to the project will earn students membership on the Rose-Hulman iGEM team and attribution in iGEM competition materials.", "lemma": "BIO Synthetic Biology Laboratory Credit Hours: (studio format, day x hrs)  Term Available: Spring u1 Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: Instructor Consent Corequisites: None Open majors. project-based studio laboratory course focus fundamental laboratory technique employ synthetic biology laboratory. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Biomathematics/bmth-311.html", "text": "BMTH 311 - Systems Biology\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (even years)\nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: MA 222\nCorequisites: None\nThe study of how to combine detailed biological information to build models of entire systems. Nearly any biological scale can be considered. For example, at the biochemistry level the course will consider topics such as gene regulatory networks, protein interaction networks, and metabolisms. Moving toward larger scales, systems biology can be used to study the growth of cancerous tumors, and on an even larger scale, the mating and social structure of populations. The course's focus is on how to use relational information to perform model based inquiries of an entire system.", "lemma": "BMTH Systems Biology Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (even years) Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: MA Corequisites: None study combine detailed biological information build model entire systems. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Chemistry/chem-582.html", "text": "CHEM 582 - Physical Properties of Polymeric Materials\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring ee Dept\nGraduate Studies Eligible: Yes\nPrerequisites: CHEM 361 or CHEM 360\nCorequisites: None\nIn this course the physical properties of polymeric systems will be defined in terms of the models that have been used to characterize them. The behavior of isolated polymers and polymers in solution will be mapped to macroscopic properties of bulk polymeric systems using theories such as Rotational Isomeric State and Flory\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Lattice model. Methods of molecular weight determination will be fully developed. Phase transitions will be characterized and related to polymeric and monomeric structural features. Theories of elasticity and viscoelastic behavior will be used to explain macroscopic behaviors of polymeric materials.", "lemma": "CHEM Physical Properties Polymeric Materials Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring ee Dept Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: CHEM CHEM Corequisites: None course physical property polymeric system be define term model have be use characterize behavior isolated polymer polymer solution be map macroscopic property bulk polymeric system use theory such Rotational Isomeric State Flory\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Lattice model. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-240.html", "text": "CSSE 240 - Principles of Cybersecurity\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: CSSE 120 and HUM H190\nCorequisites: None\nThis course introduces ethical, theoretical, and practical issues of information security in interconnected systems of computers. Implications of relevant professional codes of ethics are a recurring theme of the course, as are societal and human impacts on computer system security. Foundational topics include access control matrices and standard system models, as well as policies for security, confidentiality, and integrity. Implementation issues include key management, cipher techniques, authentication, principles of secure design, representation of identity, access control mechanisms, information flow, life cycle issues, and formal evaluation and certification techniques. Additional topics include malicious logic, vulnerability analysis, and auditing. Computer system attack techniques are observed and evaluated in a closed environment to motivate and inform discussion and exploration of computer network defense techniques.", "lemma": "CSSE Principles Cybersecurity Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: CSSE HUM H190 Corequisites: None course introduce ethical, theoretical, practical issue information security interconnected system computers. Foundational topic include access control matrix standard system models, as well policy security, confidentiality, integrity. Implementation issue include key cipher techniques, authentication, principle secure design, representation identity, access control mechanisms, information flow, life cycle issues, formal evaluation certification techniques. Additional topic include malicious logic, vulnerability analysis, auditing. Computer system attack technique be observe evaluate closed environment motivate inform discussion exploration computer network defense techniques."}

Exposes students to the procedures and complexities of working on projects that span many time-zones and cultures. Additionally, students examine the use and impact of computing in a global community. International travel is required; students will be expected to incur additional expenses (will vary depending on the project, institution, and country). {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-242.html", "text": "CSSE 242 - Programming in the Community\nCredit Hours: Variable  Term Available: Fall , Winter , Spring \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: None\nCorequisites: None\nProgramming in the Community is a unique course where Rose-Hulman students learn how to become teachers in Computer Science for younger students. As the name suggests, students will go teach CS material to K-12 students at their local school. Students will be assigned to a teaching team to take turns leading and helping follow along projects for the K-12 students. Students are expected to join a weekly instructor meeting on Teams, then take two teaching trips into the community per week (40 to 50 minute lessons). Transportation can be arranged for students unable to travel to the school. Students of any major are welcome to join. This class is a very real-world experience. It is a great way to learn leadership and teaching skills while doing great community service. May be repeated up to 12 credit hours.", "lemma": "CSSE Programming Community Credit Hours: Variable  Term Available: Fall , Winter , Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: None Corequisites: None Programming Community be unique course Rose-Hulman student learn become teacher Computer Science young students. name suggests, student go teach CS material K-12 student local school. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-340.html", "text": "CSSE 340 - Foundations of Cybersecurity\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: CSSE 132 and CSSE 280\nCorequisites: None\nThis course introduces ethical, theoretical, and practical issues of information security in interconnected systems of computers. Implications of relevant professional codes of ethics are a recurring theme of the course, as are societal and human impacts on computer system security. Foundational topics include access control matrices and standard system models, as well as policies for security, confidentiality, and integrity. Implementation issues include key management, cipher techniques, authentication, principles of secure design, representation of identity, access control mechanisms, information flow, life cycle issues, and formal evaluation and certification techniques. Additional topics include malicious logic, vulnerability analysis, and auditing. Computer system attack techniques are discussed and explored in a closed environment to motivate and inform discussion and exploration of computer network defense techniques.", "lemma": "CSSE Foundations Cybersecurity Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: CSSE CSSE Corequisites: None course introduce ethical, theoretical, practical issue information security interconnected system computers. Additional topic include malicious logic, vulnerability analysis, auditing. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-402.html", "text": "CSSE 402 - Theory and Practice of Garbage Collection\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: -\nGraduate Studies Eligible: Yes\nPrerequisites: CSSE 332\nCorequisites: None\nGarbage collection (GC) is a method of automatically reclaiming dynamically allocated storage that an application no longer needs. In this course, students will explore the classical problems of garbage collection such as detecting unused objects and reclaiming the space allocated to them. Students will survey the GC literature to become familiar with the current state-of-the-art and future research directions. Students will explore techniques used to implement state-of-the-art garbage collection algorithms and will design and implement garbage collectors for a memory-managed language (e.g.,Java, C#, php, or Python).", "lemma": "CSSE Theory Practice Garbage Collection Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: CSSE Corequisites: None Garbage collection (GC) be method automatically reclaim dynamically allocate storage application no longer needs. course, student explore classical problem garbage collection such detect unused object reclaim space allocate them. Students survey GC literature become familiar current state-of-the-art future research directions. Students explore technique use implement state-of-the-art garbage collection algorithm design implement garbage collector memory-managed language (e.g.,Java, C#, php, Python)."}

What limits exist on what problems computers can solve? What does it mean for a problem to be hard? Topics include models of computation (including Turing machines), undecidability (including the Halting Problem) and computational complexity (including NP-completeness). Same as MA 474.", "lemma": "CSSE Theory Computation Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: CSSE MA MA Corequisites: None Students study mathematical model answer questions: be computer? limit exist problem computer solve? do mean problem be hard? {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-481.html", "text": "CSSE 481 - Web-Based Information Systems\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (odd years)\nGraduate Studies Eligible: Yes\nPrerequisites: CSSE 230\nCorequisites: None\nIn this course, students learn about several aspects of research: thinking creatively about interesting research problems, researching existing work in a chosen area, and keeping current in a field. Students are exposed to the process of research by writing a pre-proposal for a project that advances the web. Projects either develop new web-technologies or applications or investigate a topic of importance. Based on feedback received, groups of students write a research proposal which goes through a formal peer review process. Approved projects are pursued for the remainder of the quarter. Students present current research as well as give a final presentation of their group project. Selected web-technologies are introduced; in the past, these have included CGI programming and XML technologies.", "lemma": "CSSE Web-Based Information Systems Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (odd years) Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: CSSE Corequisites: None course, student learn several aspect research: think creatively interest research problems, research exist work chosen area, keep current field. Students present current research as well give final presentation group project. Selected web-technologies be introduced; past, have include CGI programming XML technologies."}

{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Computer%20Science/csse-497.html", "text": "CSSE 497 - Senior Capstone Project I\nCredit Hours: 4 Term Available: Fall \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: CSSE 371, CSSE 374* and senior standing\nCorequisites: None\nFor a capstone experience, students work on a team to complete a three-term software engineering project for an approved client. Students choose from two approaches to complete their capstone: 1) Develop a substantive software product, using defensible software processes. The teams focus on delivering key software development, administrative, and user artifacts to the client. Tasks include project planning, risk analysis, use of standards, prototyping, configuration management, quality assurance, project reviews and reports, team management and organization, copyright, liability, and handling project failure. 2) Investigate a substantive software product or engineering process problem, using a defensible and documented research approach. Tasks include problem analysis, developing alternative solutions, evaluating the solutions via prototyping and iterative processes of investigation, comparing the potential solutions, recording the investigation experience in a research report, and delivering the research artifacts to the client.", "lemma": "CSSE Senior Capstone Project Credit Hours:  Term Available: Fall Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: CSSE CSSE senior stand Corequisites: None capstone experience, student work team complete three-term software engineering project approved client. Tasks include project planning, risk analysis, use standards, prototyping, configuration quality assurance, project review reports, team management organization, copyright, liability, handle project failure. Investigate substantive software product engineering process problem, use defensible document research approach. Tasks include problem develop alternative solutions, evaluate solution prototyping iterative process investigation, compare potential solutions, record investigation experience research report, deliver research artifacts client."}

{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Electrical%20Engineering/ece-203.html", "text": "ECE 203 - DC Circuits\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring , Fall \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: MA 111 and PH 112\nCorequisites: None\nA review of the definition of voltage, current, energy and power. An introduction to Ohm\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Law, ideal DC independent and dependent voltage and current sources, resistors, inductors, capacitors, and operational amplifiers. Circuit analysis and simplification by using series, parallel, and Wye-Delta reduction, Kirchhoff\u00e2\u0080\u0099s laws, mesh and nodal analysis, Thevenin, Norton and Maximum Power Theorems, superposition, and source transformations. An integral laboratory to build electric circuits and measure voltage, current, resistance and power.", "lemma": "ECE DC Circuits Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring , Fall Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: MA PH Corequisites: None A review definition voltage, current, energy power. introduction Ohm\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Law, ideal DC independent dependent voltage current sources, resistors, inductors, capacitors, operational amplifiers. Circuit analysis simplification use series, parallel, Wye-Delta reduction, Kirchhoff\u00e2\u0080\u0099s laws, mesh nodal analysis, Thevenin, Norton Maximum Power Theorems, superposition, source transformations. integral laboratory build electric circuit measure voltage, current, resistance power."}

Ideal and non-ideal transformer models. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Engineering%20Management/emgt-464.html", "text": "EMGT 464 - Systems Architecture\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: -\nPrerequisites: None\nCorequisites: None\nThis class will introduce students to the art and science of systems architecting, where systems architecting refers to uncovering the fundamental structure of a system (functional, physical, logical, operational) defined in terms of system\u00e2\u0080\u0099s elements, interfaces, processes, constraints, and behaviors that must operate under specific requirements and constraints. Focus will be placed on investigating the broader meaning of architectures, as they relate to organizations and businesses, in addition to engineered systems and products. Students will be introduced to heuristic and model-based approaches for systems architecting. Through case-studies and example problems in areas of production and manufacturing systems, intelligent transportation systems, social systems, and others, students will be able to apply the principles, processes and tools of systems architecting in order to structure and support the system development process of a balanced, well-integrated and socially and financially acceptable system.", "lemma": "EMGT Systems Architecture Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Prerequisites: None Corequisites: None class introduce student art science system architecting, system architecting refers uncover fundamental structure system (functional, physical, logical, operational) define term system\u00e2\u0080\u0099s elements, interfaces, processes, constraints, behavior operate specific requirement constraints. Focus be place investigate broad meaning architectures, relate organization businesses, addition engineer system products. Students be introduce heuristic model-based approach system architecting. case-studies example problem area production manufacturing systems, intelligent transportation systems, social systems, others, student be able apply principles, process tool system architecting order structure support system development process balanced, well-integrated socially financially acceptable system."}
{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Engineering%20Management/emgt-467.html", "text": "EMGT 467 - Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: -\nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: None\nCorequisites: None\nThis class will introduce students to critical principles of economic analysis of engineering projects. In particular, students will explore the process of making economic decisions under the influence of possibly uncertain future conditions and events. These economic decisions might involve investing in new facilities, improving existing production processes, or developing and marketing new products or services in the private and public sectors. Deterministic and multi-attribute evaluation approaches will be discussed. Students will be introduced to methodologies including capital budgeting, cost estimating, various alternative comparison methods, and life cycle costing. Additionally, students will be introduced to the concept of welfare economics through which they will explore economic impacts of infrastructure projects in the public sector. Emphasis will be placed on systems thinking and a systems approach to defining and solving economic problems.", "lemma": "EMGT Economic Analysis Engineering Projects Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: None Corequisites: None class introduce student critical principle economic analysis engineering projects. particular, student explore process make economic decision influence possibly uncertain future condition events. economic decision involve invest new facilities, improve exist production processes, developing marketing new product service private public sectors. Emphasis be place system think system approach define solve economic problems."}

Focus will be placed on investigating the broader meaning of architectures, as they relate to organizations and businesses, in addition to engineered systems and products. Students will be introduced to heuristic and model-based approaches for systems architecting. Through case-studies and example problems in areas of production and manufacturing systems, intelligent transportation systems, social systems, and others, students will be able to apply the principles, processes and tools of systems architecting in order to structure and support the system development process of a balanced, well-integrated and socially and financially acceptable system. In particular, students will explore the process of making economic decisions under the influence of possibly uncertain future conditions and events. These economic decisions might involve investing in new facilities, improving existing production processes, or developing and marketing new products or services in the private and public sectors. Deterministic and multi-attribute evaluation approaches will be discussed. Students will be introduced to methodologies including capital budgeting, cost estimating, various alternative comparison methods, and life cycle costing. Additionally, students will be introduced to the concept of welfare economics through which they will explore economic impacts of infrastructure projects in the public sector. Emphasis will be placed on systems thinking and a systems approach to defining and solving economic problems. A student may not receive credit for both EMGT467 and EMGT567. Students enrolled in EMGT567 must complete a project not covered in EMGT467.", "lemma": "EMGT Economic Analysis Engineering Projects Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: Senior standing consent instructor Corequisites: None class introduce student critical principle economic analysis engineering projects. particular, student explore process make economic decision influence possibly uncertain future condition events. economic decision involve invest new facilities, improve exist production processes, developing marketing new product service private public sectors. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Engineering%20Design/engd-210.html", "text": "ENGD 210 - Systems Accounting and Modeling II\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: ENGD 200 or EM 121 or equivalent\nCorequisites: None\nA common framework for engineering analysis is extended using the concepts of a system, accounting and conservation of extensive properties, constitutive relations, constraints, and modeling assumptions. Stress, strain, and deformation under axial loading are defined. Equilibrium is defined. Conservation equations for mass, charge, momentum and energy, and an entropy accounting equation are developed. Applications are developed from multiple engineering disciplines. Students may not receive credit towards graduation for both ENGD210 and ES201.", "lemma": "ENGD Systems Accounting Modeling II Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: ENGD EM equivalent Corequisites: None A common framework engineering analysis be extend use concept system, accounting conservation extensive properties, constitutive relations, constraints, model assumptions. Applications be develop multiple engineering disciplines. Students not receive credit towards graduation ENGD210 ES201."}
{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Engineering%20Design/engd-215.html", "text": "ENGD 215 - Systems Accounting and Modeling II\nCredit Hours:3 Term Available: Spring \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: ENGD 205 or EM 121 or equivalent\nCorequisites: None\nThis course is a continuation of ENGD 205 and emphasizes engineering problem solving using common engineering science concepts: systems, conservation and accounting principles for extensive properties, material properties, constitutive equations, and physical constraints. This framework, combined with appropriate mathematics, provides a powerful tool for modeling and predicting the behavior of the physical world. The course introduces two- and three-dimensional force systems, equilibrium, distributed forces, and strength and elastic deflection of engineering materials under axial loading. Students may not receive credit towards graduation for both ENGD215 and ES201.", "lemma": "ENGD Systems Accounting Modeling II Credit Hours:3 Term Available: Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: ENGD EM equivalent Corequisites: None course be continuation ENGD emphasize engineering problem solve use common engineering science concepts: systems, conservation accounting principle extensive properties, material properties, constitutive equations, physical constraints. framework, combine appropriate mathematics, provide powerful tool modeling predict behavior physical world. course introduce two- three-dimensional force systems, equilibrium, distribute forces, strength elastic deflection engineering material axial loading. Failure types considered include Rupture, Fatigue, Creep, Corrosion, Electromigration, Electrical Overstress, Electrical Discharge and Thermal. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Mathematics/ma-223.html", "text": "MA 223 - Engineering Statistics I\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall ,Winter ,Spring \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: MA 111 and ENGL H100 or ENGD 100 or HUM H190\nCorequisites: None\nThis is an introductory course in applied statistics emphasizing data analysis. The course is designed to support the research cycle including the formulation of a question of interest, effective data collection techniques, informative data summaries, and appropriate inferences from data. Communication of results and statistical concepts is emphasized. Statistical software will be used for the data analysis throughout, including analysis of variance and simple linear regression. A student cannot take both MA223 and MA382 for credit.", "lemma": "MA Engineering Statistics Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall ,Winter ,Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: MA ENGL H100 ENGD HUM H190 Corequisites: None be introductory course applied statistic emphasize data analysis. course be design support research cycle include formulation question interest, effective data collection informative data summaries, appropriate inference data. {"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Mathematics/ma-438.html", "text": "MA 438 - Advanced Engineering Mathematics\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: MA 222 and senior standing\nCorequisites: None\nA fast-paced course in advanced applied mathematics for engineering and physics students that combines aspects of MA330, MA336, and MA373. Applied linear algebra, including abstract vector spaces, linear operators, eigentheory, diagonalization, and the matrix exponential; review of partial differentiation and multiple integration, including Lagrange multipliers and other optimization topics; vector analysis, including the Jacobian matrix and the del operator in standard coordinate systems; and Fourier series with application to the solution of partial differential equation boundary value problems. Students who receive credit for MA438 may only receive credit for at most one of MA330, MA336, MA371, and MA373.", "lemma": "MA Advanced Engineering Mathematics Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: MA senior stand Corequisites: None A fast-paced course advanced applied mathematics engineering physic student combine aspect MA330, MA336, MA373. Students receive credit MA438 only receive credit most MA330, MA336, MA371, MA373."}
{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Mathematics/ma-439.html", "text": "MA 439 - Mathematical Methods of Image Processing\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (Odd years)\nGraduate Studies Eligible: Yes\nPrerequisites: MA 221\nCorequisites: None\nMathematical formulation and development of methods used in image processing, especially compression. Vector space models of signals and images, one- and two-dimensional discrete Fourier transforms, the discrete cosine transform, and block transforms. Frequency domain, basis waveforms, and frequency domain representation of signals and images. Convolution and filtering. Filter banks, wavelets and the discrete wavelet transform. Application to Fourier based and wavelet based compression such as the JPEG compression standard. Compression concepts such as scalar quantization and measures of performance.", "lemma": "MA Mathematical Methods Image Processing Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Fall (Odd years) Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: MA Corequisites: None Mathematical formulation development method use image processing, especially compression. Application Fourier base wavelet base compression such JPEG compression standard. Compression concept such scalar quantization measure performance."}

{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Mathematics/ma-482.html", "text": "MA 482 - Biostatistics\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring \nGraduate Studies Eligible: No\nPrerequisites: MA 223 or MA 382\nCorequisites: None\nThis course introduces statistical techniques for addressing the challenges that arise in the analysis of data from the biological sciences (including biology, biomedical engineering, and the medical community). Topics include linear regression modeling, nonlinear regression, repeated measures analysis (including mixed models), and survival/reliability analysis (analysis of time-to-event data). Flexible modeling strategies including relaxing linearity and distributional assumptions are discussed. Additional topics are introduced when discussing articles found in the literature, including properties of study design, power, meta-analysis, missing data, and causal inference. No prerequisite knowledge of biology is assumed. Review of fundamental prerequisite statistics will be included as necessary.", "lemma": "MA Biostatistics Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Spring Graduate Studies Eligible: No Prerequisites: MA MA Corequisites: None course introduce statistical technique address challenge arise analysis data biological science (including biology, biomedical engineering, medical community). Topics include linear regression modeling, nonlinear regression, repeat measure analysis (including mixed models), survival/reliability analysis (analysis time-to-event data). Flexible modeling strategy include relax linearity distributional assumption be discussed. Additional topic be introduce discuss article find literature, include property study design, power, meta-analysis, miss data, causal inference. No prerequisite knowledge biology be assumed. Review fundamental prerequisite statistic be include necessary."}
{"source": "https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/course-catalog/current/programs/Mathematics/ma-483.html", "text": "MA 483 - Bayesian Data Analysis\nCredit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter (Odd years)\nGraduate Studies Eligible: Yes\nPrerequisites: MA 381\nCorequisites: None\nThis course offers an introduction to statistical inference under the Bayesian framework in addition to elements of basic study design. Building from Bayes' Rule for probability computations, we develop a framework of estimation, hypothesis testing and prediction. Topics include the construction of prior distributions to quantify a priori beliefs about unknown parameters, modeling available data, and using data to update beliefs about parameters. Applications include inference for a single response, comparing groups, and regression models; modern applications will be covered, time permitting. The course will make use of heavy use of computational tools for Bayesian inference, including Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods.", "lemma": "MA Bayesian Data Analysis Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter (Odd years) Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: MA Corequisites: None course offer introduction statistical inference Bayesian framework addition element basic study design. Building Bayes' Rule probability computations, develop framework estimation, hypothesis testing prediction. Topics include construction prior distribution quantify priori belief unknown parameters, model available data, use data update belief parameters. Applications include inference single response, compare groups, regression models; modern application be covered, time permitting. course make use heavy use computational tool Bayesian inference, include Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods."}

Emphasis is placed on designing statistical studies to solve problems in engineering and science. A variety of designs are presented, including the full factorial, screening, response surface, and split plot. It is demonstrated how constraints on the randomization process due to the design are related to the appropriate analysis method and meaning of the results. Statistical software is used for data analysis throughout.", "lemma": "MA Design Experiments Credit Hours:4 Term Available: Winter (even years) Graduate Studies Eligible: Yes Prerequisites: MA MA Corequisites: None be applied course design experiments.
